questions.text: A previously healthy 24-year-old man comes to the physician 1 day after the onset of burning pain, swelling, and multiple blisters over the left index finger. He works as a dental assistant and is concerned about not being able to work. The patient wonders if the symptoms might be related to a hunting trip he returned from 1 week ago because he remembers seeing a lot of poison oak. He is sexually active with one female partner, and they do not use condoms. His father has a history of thromboangiitis obliterans. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 5 years. He drinks two to four beers on social occasions. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows swelling and erythema of the pulp space of the left index finger; there are multiple 3-mm vesicles. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 12,000 cells/mm3. In addition to supportive therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Incision and drainage of the pulp space

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Acyclovir is an antiviral medication used to treat herpes simplex infections, such as herpetic whitlow. In addition, bandages should be applied to avoid the spread of infection, and analgesics can be used for pain. Without treatment, herpetic whitlow is usually self-limiting and resolves within 2–3 weeks; therefore, most patients do not require antiviral treatment. However, treatment is appropriate to shorten the disease course and allow patients to return to work.
Image Description:

A cluster of three nonpurulent vesicles on an erythematous base is visible on the distal phalanx. The surrounding skin is intact.

This is the characteristic appearance of herpetic whitlow.

B) INCORRECT:

Incision and drainage of the pulp space are indicated to treat acute paronychia or felon. Both paronychia and felon manifest with swelling and pain of the finger but not vesicles. Surgical treatment is, in fact, contraindicated in patients with herpetic whitlow because it increases the risk of secondary bacterial infection.
Image Description:

Periungual erythema, swelling, and pus proximal to the nail are characteristic findings of paronychia, in this case caused by Candida.

C) INCORRECT:

Cephalexin is a first-generation cephalosporin that is effective against gram-positive cocci and some gram-negative bacilli. Thus, oral cefalexin will be effective if this man had paronychia or felon of the finger. Both paronychia and felon manifest with swelling and pain of the finger but not vesicles. Herpetic whitlow is caused by a virus; antibiotics would only help if a secondary bacterial infection were suspected.
Image Description:

The distal thumb is erythematous and swollen. At the tip, a likely pus-filled compartment is visible.

D) INCORRECT:

Warm water soaks are not indicated in the management of herpetic whitlow. They can be used to treat the early stages of acute paronychia, which manifests with pain and swelling over the nail base that expresses white pus but does not produce vesicles.

E) INCORRECT:

Intramuscular benzathine penicillin G is the treatment of choice for syphilis. This patient does not have any clinical features of primary syphilis (e.g., chancre) or secondary syphilis (e.g., maculopapular rash affecting the palms and soles, fever, malaise). In addition, syphilis does not manifest with swelling and vesicles of the fingers.

F) INCORRECT:

Smoking cessation is an important part of management for thromboangiitis obliterans (TAO), which manifests with ischemic ulcers and/or pain in the fingers that worsens with activity. Although swelling may also be present, this condition does not produce vesicles. Smoking cessation should be always be recommended, but it is not part of the management of herpetic whitlow.

G) INCORRECT:

Patients who have come into contact with allergens that precipitate contact dermatitis (e.g., poison oak) should thoroughly wash the exposed body areas. These plants usually cause a blistering rash over areas of contact within 24 hours. This patient, however, was exposed to poison oak 1 week ago. In addition, allergic contact dermatitis rarely manifests with highly localized symptoms, which are seen here, because the allergen (plant resin) is commonly transferred by affected individuals to other parts of the body. Washing the finger would not help to treat or relieve the symptoms of herpetic whitlow.
Image Description:

Marked redness, edema, plaques, and crust formation are visible on the palmar surface of the patient's left hand.

These features are suggestive of allergic contact dermatitis.
questions.hint: The patient's symptoms raise concern for herpetic whitlow.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of fever, malaise, and a painful, itchy rash on the right shoulder for 2 weeks. The patient's mother says the boy's condition has worsened over the past 4 days. He has a history of atopic dermatitis. He has lived with his mother at several public shelters since she separated from his physically abusive father 2 months ago. His immunizations are up-to-date. There is cervical lymphadenopathy. Laboratory studies show no abnormalities. A photograph of the rash is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Crowded living conditions are a risk factor for bed bug infestations. However, bed bug bites take the form of painless papules that becomes itchy and resolve spontaneously within a week. They are typically found on skin that is exposed during sleep.
Image Description:

Numerous macules and papules, both isolated and in clusters, are visible on the back.

While this finding is typical of bedbug bites, similar symptoms can appear in a wide variety of cutaneous reactions.

B) INCORRECT:

Nonbullous impetigo may cause a rash that progresses from papules to small vesicles surrounded by erythema followed by pustules that rupture. However, nonbullous impetigo primarily occurs in young children (2–6 years), is generally not painful, and is not usually accompanied by fever and malaise.
Image Description:

Dorsolateral region of the neck of a 22-month-old girl

Infection began with an erythematous macule that evolved into a cent-sized vesicle. Rupture of the vesicle and release of its serous contents was followed by the development of a typical honey-colored crust on the lesion and the spread of smaller pustules in the cervical and facial regions.

C) INCORRECT:

Stevens-Johnson syndrome causes a rash associated with fever and malaise and is often triggered by infection (e.g., mycoplasma, herpes simplex virus). However, the rash in this patient is papular in nature, unlike the blistering rash observed in Stevens-Johnson syndrome. Moreover, the rash of Stevens-Johnson syndrome typically involves sloughing and the mucosal membranes are almost always involved.
Image Description:

Back, buttocks, thighs, and legs of an 8-month-old infant 2 weeks after primary vaccination

Irregularly shaped, partially confluent, erythematous macules with bullae are visible.

Patient history suggests Stevens-Johnson syndrome triggered by vaccination.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's symptoms (fever, malaise, lymphadenopathy) and his rash indicate eczema herpeticum, a cutaneous manifestation of herpes infection (usually HSV-1 or HSV-2). This condition is associated with pre-existing skin conditions, most often atopic dermatitis. Eczema herpeticum is considered a dermatological emergency because the rash on the patient's shoulder can disseminate rapidly. Treatment with oral or IV acyclovir should be initiated as soon as possible.

E) INCORRECT:

Shingles is associated with a rash in a dermatomal distribution, typically affecting 1–3 dermatomes on one side of the body. Most patients report severe burning or throbbing pain that is followed by a rash. The rash is initially maculopapular on an erythematous base and quickly progresses to a vesicular rash. Crusting and involution typically occur after 7–10 days. This patient's immunizations are up-to-date and should include the chickenpox vaccine.
Image Description:

Left arm of a child showing multiple, uniform vesicles on an erythematous base. The dermatomal distribution (C8 and T1) is characteristic of shingles. Patients complain of severe pain prior to the appearance of lesions.

F) INCORRECT:

Scabies typically affects the interdigital folds, wrists, and ankles, and patients classically have intense pruritus that is worst at night. Although crowded, unsanitary living conditions are a risk factor for this condition, the rash associated with scabies is not painful. Moreover, fever, malaise, and lymphadenopathy are not expected.
Image Description:

Multiple erythematous papules (partially excoriated) are visible in the interdigital folds and on the dorsal aspect of the hand and fingers.

G) INCORRECT:

Chickenpox is a highly contagious viral illness that typically manifests with a widespread, pruritic rash that initially involves the trunk and quickly spreads to the face, scalp, and extremities. This patient's underlying skin condition puts him at an increased risk of developing a severe form of chickenpox and complications such as bacterial superinfection and scarring. However, his immunizations are up-to-date and should include the chickenpox vaccine.
questions.hint: This patient's condition is also known as Kaposi varicelliform eruption.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl comes to the physician with a 4-day history of painful vulvar lesions, generalized fatigue, and malaise. During this period, she has also had dysuria. She is sexually active with 2 male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Her immunizations are up-to-date; she completed the vaccination course for human papillomavirus 2 months ago. Temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows several shallow ulcers on an erythematous base over the labia majora and minora. The ulcers are 1–3 mm in diameter. There is bilateral, tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Oral acyclovir therapy is indicated for genital herpes. Antiviral treatment reduces the duration and severity of infection as well as viral shedding, and it is most effective if initiated within 72 hours of symptom onset. Antiviral therapy does not prevent recurrence.

See “Overview of sexually transmitted genital lesions” table.
Image Description:

Photograph of the anogenital region of an adult female patient

Fluid-filled vesicles on erythematous bases are visible around the anus and vulva. Some of these vesicles have ruptured, leaving erythematous ulcerations.

These findings are consistent with herpes genitalis, most likely caused by infection with herpes simplex virus type 2.

B) INCORRECT:

Curettage is used to treat warts (caused by human papillomavirus) but not genital herpes. Genital warts can be transmitted sexually but present as painless papular growths and are not associated with tender lymphadenopathy, multiple painful shallow ulcers, or malaise, making this diagnosis very unlikely. Additionally, if this patient received a tetravalent or 9-valent vaccine regimen prior to potential infection, she would likely be immune to the HPV types (primarily 6 and 11) that cause genital warts.

C) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin is commonly used in the treatment of sexually transmitted infections such as chlamydia and chancroid. Chlamydia infection is commonly asymptomatic. Symptomatic patients typically present with pelvic pain, not skin lesions and lymphadenopathy. Chancroid is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi and manifests with multiple painful papules or pustules that erode into ulcers. Chancroid ulcers are usually larger (10–20 mm) and deeper than the ones seen here, and they have a greyish necrotic base and purulent exudate.

D) INCORRECT:

Doxycycline can be used to treat both syphilitic and chlamydial infections but not genital herpes. L1–L3 serotypes of Chlamydia trachomatis cause lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV), which manifests initially with a painless papule that resolves and then causes suppurative lymphadenopathy 2–6 weeks later. Treponema pallidum is responsible for syphilis, which manifests in the primary stage as a painless round and firm ulcer with no lymph node involvement. Neither syphilis nor LGV are associated with multiple painful shallow ulcers, making them unlikely diagnoses.

E) INCORRECT:

Benzathine penicillin is effective against Treponema pallidum, the causative agent of syphilis. The primary stage of syphilis presents as a painless round ulcer called chancre that is typically a solitary lesion but can occasionally present with multiple lesions or bilateral lymphadenopathy. However, the lesion is generally painless.
questions.hint: The presence of several shallow ulcers on an erythematous base and bilateral tender inguinal lymphadenopathy in an individual with high-risk sexual behavior is indicative of genital herpes, which is diagnosed by performing a polymerase chain reaction test or viral culture on a smear obtained from the ulcer.

questions.text: A 15-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 2-day history of low-grade fever and a painful lesion on her left middle finger. She was born at term and has been healthy except for a vesicular rash on her upper lip 2 weeks ago, which resolved without treatment. She lives at home with her parents, her 5-year-old brother, and two cats. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. A photograph of the left middle finger is shown. Physical examination shows tender left epitrochlear lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sporothrix schenckii causes sporotrichosis, a fungal infection typically acquired through gardening. The fungus is found in soil and on plants and enters the skin through small lesions (e.g., a thorn prick). A painless, erythematous, or violaceous plaque develops at the site of inoculation, which is followed by new lesions appearing along the lymphatic tract after a few weeks. Systemic symptoms do not typically occur. The patient's development of painful, multiple vesicles with simultaneous onset of lymphadenopathy and fever rules out S. schenckii.
Image Description:

A linear sporotrichoid spread is visible along the draining lymphatics. Some lesions have a nodular appearance, while others show ulceration.


This is the characteristic clinical picture of a lymphogenic spreading sporotrichosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Human papillomavirus type 1 (HPV type 1) is a common cause of verruca vulgaris, also known as common warts. These typically present on the hands and feet as scaly papules, and are usually painless, though they may be pruritic. Since systemic symptoms and lymphadenopathy do not occur in verruca vulgaris, an infection with HPV type 1 can be ruled out.
Image Description:

Partially confluent, hyperkeratotic papules with a rough surface are seen on the dorsal surface of the hand at the level of the metacarpophalangeal joint

C) INCORRECT:

Group A Streptococcus (GAS) causes nonbullous impetigo, which can manifest with small vesicles surrounded by erythema and regional lymphadenopathy. However, this patient's history of a vesicular rash on the upper lip two weeks ago and the presence of systemic symptoms (i.e., fever) make a different condition more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Infection with Bartonella henselae causes cat scratch disease (CSD) and is typically transmitted by cats through scratching, biting, or licking. Although CSD causes skin lesions and regional lymphadenopathy, this condition typically manifests with painless papules and/or pustules at the cutaneous site of inoculation instead of painful vesicles. This patient's previous rash on the lip and current findings suggest a different causal organism.
Image Description:

A solitary reddish-purple papule on an erythematous base is visible on the patient's right thenar eminence.

This appearance is typical of cat scratch disease, i.e., infection with Bartonella henselae.

E) CORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) is the most common cause of herpetic whitlow, an infection of the dermal and subcutaneous tissue of the fingers (especially the thumb and index fingers). It is transmitted through direct contact between a break in the skin on the finger and infected secretions, often from primary oral lesions (e.g., labial herpes), as suggested in this patient. Children who suck their fingers and health care workers (especially dentists) are most commonly affected. The condition presents with painful, grouped, nonpurulent vesicles, usually accompanied by tingling, and burning sensations in the affected digits. Axillary and epitrochlear lymphadenopathy may also develop.

F) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of acute paronychia, a painful soft tissue infection affecting the skin around the nails of fingers and toes. Paronychia is typically purulent, unlike the skin lesion seen in this child, which suggests a nonbacterial etiology.
Image Description:

Periungual erythema, swelling, and pus proximal to the nail are characteristic findings of paronychia, in this case caused by Candida.
questions.hint: A Tzanck smear of the vesicular base will show multinucleated giant cells.

questions.text: A 17-year-old male comes to the physician because of painful genital sores, malaise, and fever for 3 days. He is sexually active with 3 female partners and does not use condoms consistently. His temperature is 38.3°C (101°F). Physical examination shows tender lymphadenopathy in the left inguinal region and multiple, punched-out ulcers over the penile shaft and glans. Microscopic examination of a smear from the ulcer is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Eosinophilic intranuclear inclusions on a smear of an ulcer or opened vesicle describe the Cowdry A inclusion bodies seen in infections by herpesviruses such as HSV-1, HSV-2, VZV, and CMV. These intranuclear inclusions are formed during herpesvirus replication within the nucleus. Another microscopic characteristic of herpesvirus infection is the formation of multinucleated giant cells as a result of the fusion of multiple infected cells (seen on Tzanck smear). HSV-2 can remain dormant in the sacral ganglia after the primary infection to cause recurrent genital herpes.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a smear from the base of a herpetic (HSV-1) gingivostomatitis lesion (Pappenheim stain; very high magnification)

A multinucleated giant cell (Tzanck cell) can be seen, indicating a positive Tzanck test.

B) INCORRECT:

Reticulate bodies, which would appear as basophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions, are seen with infections by Chlamydia trachomatis. Lymphogranuloma inguinale, which is caused by C. trachomatis serotypes L1–L3, can manifest with multiple genital ulcers, tender inguinal lymphadenopathy, and systemic symptoms. However, the genital ulcers in lymphogranuloma venereum would be painless. Basophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions are not a feature of HSV infection.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of cells in McCoy cell culture (200x magnification)

The cells infected with Chlamydia trachomatis (example circled in blue) are identifiable by inclusion bodies (brown; example marked by hatched overlay), surrounded by a thin rim of host cytoplasm. Over the course of the pathogen's life cycle, elementary bodies (examples circled in white) are formed within the inclusion bodies. These are released from the cell and serve to transmit the pathogen to other cells or hosts.

C) INCORRECT:

Eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions can be seen in infections by rhabdovirus (e.g., Negri bodies in rabies) or poxvirus (e.g., molluscum contagiosum), both of which are large viruses that replicate in the cytoplasm. Molluscum contagiosum can manifest with genital lesions, but the lesions would be flesh-colored, pearly, dome-shaped, or umbilicated papules, unlike the punched-out ulcers in this patient. Rabies is a terminal CNS disease characterized by insanity and hydrophobia, and Negri bodies would occur only in neurons. Eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions are not a feature of HSV infection.

Non-infectious conditions associated with eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions include Parkinson disease (Lewy bodies), Leydig cell tumors (Reinke crystals), and alcohol-associated liver disease (Mallory bodies).
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of brain tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

A pyramidal cell (green overlay) is visible in the center of the image. The distinct eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions within the pyramidal cells are Negri bodies (examples indicated by black arrowheads and white dashed outlines).

Negri bodies are most commonly found within the pyramidal cells of hippocampus and the Purkinje cells of patients infected by the rabies virus. Although the presence of Negri bodies is pathognomonic of rabies, their absence does not rule out infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Basophilic intranuclear inclusions can be seen, e.g., in adenovirus infections, which typically manifest with pharyngitis, conjunctivitis, pneumonia, acute hemorrhagic cystitis, gastroenteritis, or myocarditis. Basophilic intranuclear inclusions are not a feature of HSV infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Bipolar-staining intracytoplasmic inclusions (Donovan bodies) would be seen in cases of granuloma inguinale, which is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. Granuloma inguinale typically manifests as a single, painless, beefy red ulcer without lymphadenopathy or systemic signs of infection. Bipolar-staining intracytoplasmic inclusions are not a feature of HSV infection.
Image Description:

Exudate smear (Giemsa stain)

Coccobacilli are visible as inclusion bodies within macrophages (Donovan bodies). In some cases, the characteristic safety pin shape can be seen (examples indicated by arrowheads).
questions.hint: This patient's presentation of tender inguinal lymphadenopathy, multiple punched-out ulcers, and systemic signs of infection (e.g., malaise, fever) suggest herpes genitalis, which is typically caused by herpes simplex virus 2 (HSV-2).

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a recurrent vesicular genital rash comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of a painful, pruritic rash that began on the extremities and has spread to her trunk. Her only medication is acyclovir. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F). Examination of the skin shows several reddish-purple papules and macules, some of which have a dusky center with a lighter ring around them. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Eczema herpeticum is a complication of atopic dermatitis caused by herpes simplex virus infection and typically manifests as a widespread rash with painful, vesicular lesions. This patient does not have a reported history of atopic dermatitis and the target lesions make this an unlikely diagnosis.
Image Description:

Multiple monomorphic, umbilicated, vesicular papules and punched-out erosions with hemorrhagic crusts are visible on the back of a young patient with a history of atopic eczema.

These findings are consistent with eczema herpeticum, a dermatological emergency requiring urgent evaluation and immediate antiviral therapy. Lesions located near the eyes require referral to ophthalmology due to the risk for corneal involvement.

B) CORRECT:

This patient with recurrent genital HSV and a painful exanthem with target lesions most likely has erythema multiforme (EM). EM is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction of the skin that can be triggered by certain infections (e.g., HSV, Mycoplasma pneumoniae) and medications (e.g., beta-lactam antibiotics, sulfonamides, phenytoin). EM is characterized by lesions of varying morphology (e.g., macules, papules, vesicles) that typically progress to target lesions and spread proximally from the backs of the hands and feet, as seen here. In EM minor, mucous membranes are not or only minimally involved while in EM major, mucosal involvement occurs. Nikolsky sign is negative and the disease course is self-limiting in most cases.
Image Description:

Multiple circular lesions with a central papule and raised edges (also called “target lesions”), surrounded by a lighter edematous area, are visible on the anterior aspect of the thighs.

This is the typical appearance of erythema multiforme.

C) INCORRECT:

Urticaria (hives) is a type I hypersensitivity reaction that results from IgE-mediated mast cell degranulation. Urticaria is associated with certain medications (e.g., beta-lactam antibiotics) and infections (e.g., Mycoplasma pneumoniae) and typically manifests as a pruritic, raised erythematous rash. In contrast to the rash seen in this patient, urticaria is typically painless, well-circumscribed, and usually disappears after a few hours.
Image Description:

Multiple well-defined, erythematous, partially confluent lesions with raised serpiginous borders and central clearing are visible.

This is the characteristic appearance of urticaria, which typically has an acute onset, is highly pruritic, and transient.

D) INCORRECT:

Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) is a life-threatening type IV hypersensitivity reaction of the skin that can be triggered by certain medications (e.g., beta-lactam antibiotics, sulfonamides, lamotrigine) and infections (e.g., Mycoplasma pneumoniae). SJS can manifest with a painful rash with targetoid lesions, as seen in this patient. However, skin involvement in SJS is typically localized to the face and trunk. Moreover, this patient lacks other characteristic findings of SJS, such as high fever, epidermal detachment with a positive Nikolsky sign, skin necrosis, and involvement of mucous membranes.
Image Description:

Widespread mucocutaneous necrosis with patches of complete epidermal destruction and involvement of the lips are visible.

These findings are suggestive for the SJS, which is triggered by pharmacological treatment (e.g., with antibiotics, antiepileptics).

E) INCORRECT:

Dermatitis herpetiformis is an IgA-mediated skin reaction that is associated with celiac disease and typically manifests as a pruritic, painful papulovesicular rash. However, this patient does not have a history of gluten sensitivity, malabsorption, or gastrointestinal symptoms. Moreover, targetoid skin lesions, which are seen in this patient, would not be expected.
Image Description:

Grouped, erythematous, papulovesicular lesions that are partially excoriated (presumably due to pruritus) can be seen on the dorsal forearm.

These findings, especially in combination with pruritus, suggest dermatitis herpetiformis.
questions.hint: This patient's rash is most commonly associated with herpes simplex infections and is characterized by target lesions (macules with a dusky center surrounded by a lighter ring).

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of a red, itchy, burning rash on her vulva. She has had three similar episodes over the last two years that have all self-resolved. Genitourinary examination shows a small area of erythema with an overlying cluster of vesicles on the inside surface of the vulva. Latent infection of which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient's recurrent symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Establishment of latency in tissue macrophages is the mechanism underlying Mycobacterium tuberculosis reactivation. After primary infection, M. tuberculosis resides inside macrophages and avoids destruction by impairment of phagolysosome formation. This mechanism allows the bacteria to remain viable for many years until T cell function is compromised (e.g., immunosuppression, malnutrition), which can cause active tuberculosis due to reactivation of dormant organisms. HSV does not establish latency in macrophages.

B) CORRECT:

Latency and reactivation in the dorsal root ganglion of host sensory neurons is the mechanism underlying the recurrent symptoms seen in herpes simplex virus 1 and 2 infection. Infection with HSV is generally acquired by direct contact with mucosal tissue or secretions of an infected person. After inoculation, the virus invades, spreads, and replicates in nerve cells, producing either asymptomatic infection or acute gingivostomatitis/genital herpes. Under certain conditions (e.g., immunodeficiency, stress, trauma), HSV may reactivate and multiply in the dorsal root ganglia of the trigeminal (HSV-1) or sacral (HSV-2) nerves, producing recurrent flares, as are seen in this patient.

HSV recurrence can be prevented with guanosine analogs (e.g., acyclovir, valacyclovir), which prevent the proliferation of the virus once reactivation begins. Barrier contraception (e.g., condoms) are the only method to prevent initial infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Establishment of latency in peripheral monocyte cells is the mechanism underlying CMV reactivation. Following primary infection with CMV, the virus establishes latency in cells of the mononuclear phagocytic system. CMV reactivation typically occurs in immunocompromised patients (e.g., HIV, organ transplantation) and can present with CMV retinitis, CMV pneumonia, and CMV esophagitis. HSV does not establish latency in monocytes.

D) INCORRECT:

Establishment of latency within astrocytes and oligodendrocytes is the mechanism underlying JC virus infection reactivation. After inoculation, JC virus spreads to a variety of cells and produces asymptomatic viremia. Impaired cellular immunity (e.g., due to AIDS) allows the JC virus to invade and replicate extensively in the brain, which leads to the development of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML). HSV does not establish latency in astrocytes.

E) INCORRECT:

Low-grade replication within host T cells is a mechanism underlying latency in human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection, but not HSV reinfection, which this patient has. Upon inoculation, HIV invades, spreads, and replicates in several immune cells, which produces acute, nonspecific (e.g., flu-like) symptoms in a process known as acute retroviral syndrome. After acute infection subsides, most of the individuals remain clinically asymptomatic until the host defensive mechanisms are severely impaired and AIDS develops.
questions.hint: This patient with acute onset of itchy, burning rash and grouped vesicles on genital examination has recurrent genital herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of painful swallowing and retrosternal pain. She was diagnosed with HIV infection 2 months ago; her medications include tenofovir, emtricitabine, and raltegravir. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination of the oral cavity shows no abnormalities. The patient's CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 70/mm3. Empiric treatment is started. Two weeks later, she reports no improvement in symptoms. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy is performed and shows multiple round superficial ulcers in the distal esophagus. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Degeneration of ganglion cells within the myenteric plexuses

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is caused by gastroesophageal junction incompetence leading to reflux of stomach contents into the esophagus. Symptoms are usually chronic and episodic in nature and can include heartburn, regurgitation sensation, chronic cough, and retrosternal chest pain. Dysphagia and odynophagia are not typical and are considered red flag symptoms, which should prompt further evaluation (usually with EGD). This patient's EGD findings are not typical for GERD and her HIV-positive status makes a different etiology more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Drug-induced esophagitis (also referred to as pill esophagitis) is caused by prolonged contact with caustic medications, leading to esophageal mucosal irritation, erosion, and ulceration. Commonly implicated medications include antibiotics (tetracycline, doxycycline, clindamycin), NSAIDs, bisphosphonates, and iron pills. Zidovudine, an antiretroviral medication commonly used in patients with HIV, can also cause pill esophagitis. However, none of this patient's current medications are known to cause esophagitis. In addition, EGD findings in a patient with pill esophagitis typically demonstrate punched-out mucosa with inflammation of the surrounding mucosa.

C) INCORRECT:

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection is an important cause of esophagitis to consider in immunocompromised patients. However, CMV infections typically only occur when CD4 counts are < 50/mm3. Classic EGD findings are deep linear or longitudinal ulcers and distal mucosal erosion, unlike the round, superficial ulcers seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Achalasia, caused by the degeneration of ganglion cells in the myenteric plexus of the esophagus, may present with dysphagia, retrosternal pain, and regurgitation. EGD findings are typically normal, and the diagnosis is confirmed with manometry or barium esophagram (classic “bird-beak” appearance). This patient's odynophagia and presence of ulcers on EGD suggest a different diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Diffuse esophageal spasm (DES) may present with dysphagia and squeezing retrosternal chest pain, though there are often predictable triggers (e.g., caffeine, hot or cold foods). EGD would show normal esophageal mucosa and the diagnosis is confirmed with barium esophagram (classic finding is corkscrew esophagus). This patient's odynophagia and ulcers on endoscopy are not consistent with DES and suggest a different diagnosis.

DES is often confused with cardiac chest pain, as it may present similarly and is also relieved by nitrates.

F) INCORRECT:

Eosinophilic esophagitis is a poorly understood type of esophagitis that likely occurs in response to allergens and is mediated by eosinophil release. Diagnosis consists of identification of mucosal eosinophilia on esophageal biopsies. Most patients present with recurrent dysphagia and food impaction, rather than odynophagia. Typical findings on EGD include circumferential mucosal lesions and mucosal fragility.
Image Description:

Endoscopic image of the esophagus

Circumferential mucosal lesions (rings/corrugations; examples indicated by blue overlay) are visible.

Yellow lines: longitudinal furrows; Dashed encirclement: Z-line

G) CORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus (HSV) esophagitis can occur in patients with HIV and CD4 counts < 100/mm3 and is considered an AIDS-defining condition. Typical EGD findings include multiple round, superficial ulcers, and friable mucosa. Biopsy with viral culture or PCR can confirm the diagnosis, and treatment is with acyclovir. In this case, the patient was appropriately treated with empiric fluconazole (esophageal candidiasis is much more common than HSV esophagitis). However, the lack of clinical response prompted further investigation.
Image Description:

Endoscopic view of the esophagus

Multiple well-circumscribed, confluent ulcers (examples indicated by green overlay) are visible in the distal (lower) esophagus.

These findings are consistent with herpes esophagitis. Histopathology is necessary to confirm the diagnosis.

H) INCORRECT:

Candida species cause the vast majority of HIV-associated esophagitis, and for this reason, patients with HIV and odynophagia are usually treated empirically with fluconazole. This patient's lack of clinical response to empiric fluconazole makes esophageal candidiasis unlikely. Additionally, EGD findings in esophageal candidiasis typically include whitish/yellow plaques lining the esophageal mucosa, unlike the superficial ulcers seen in this patient. Lastly, oral thrush is usually also present.
Image Description:

Endoscopic view of the esophagus

Multiple confluent, white-gray plaques in a longitudinal pattern are visible.

These findings are characteristic of Candida esophagitis.
questions.hint: This patient is immunosuppressed and presented with odynophagia, which suggests esophagitis. Esophagitis in HIV-positive patients is typically treated empirically with fluconazole. The patient has failed this empiric treatment.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of groin pain. Yesterday, he noticed painful blebs on his penis, which he has never had before. He does not have dysuria. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His only medications are ramipril and metformin. He is sexually active with multiple male and female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. He has no family history of serious illness. He appears ill and uncomfortable. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 134/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows tender inguinal lymphadenopathy bilaterally. There are multiple grouped vesicular lesions with underlying erythema on the base of the penis. Which of the following is the most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Serological antibody test differentiates between HSV-1 and HSV-2. This test is not used in active, primary genital herpes infections because patients may present before seroconversion. Serological antibody testing is indicated in patients with a history of genital vesicular lesions who have had a negative real-time PCR or viral culture or who have a sexual partner with a known HSV infection. Furthermore, serologic antibody testing is indicated in pregnant women with an active genital lesion to classify the maternal infection as primary or nonprimary and to determine the HSV subtype, because these criteria are important for the prognostication of vertical transmission to the infant.

B) CORRECT:

Viral culture can confirm HSV infection, especially in the early stages of infection when fresh vesicular lesions are present. Other diagnostic tests include real-time PCR, which is generally the preferred confirmatory diagnostic test when available because it is more sensitive than viral culture. Serum antibody testing is another diagnostic test for HSV infection, but it cannot be used for primary infections because specific antibodies only develop following seroconversion. Tzanck smear is no longer used in the diagnosis of HSV infections because it has a low sensitivity and specificity and does not differentiate between HSV-1 and HSV-2.

C) INCORRECT:

Darkfield microscopy is used to detect Treponema pallidum in primary and secondary syphilis when specimens can be obtained from skin lesions (e.g., primary genital lesion, condyloma). Primary syphilis causes genital lesions that are typically single, painless ulcers with indurated borders rather than painful vesicular lesions like the ones seen in this patient. Additionally, patients with primary syphilis develop nontender rather than painful inguinal lymphadenopathy and usually do not have systemic symptoms such as fever and malaise.

D) INCORRECT:

A pathergy skin test is used in the diagnostic workup for Behcet disease. This condition can cause genital lesions, which are ulcerating rather than vesicular lesions like the ones seen in this patient. Additionally, Behcet disease typically causes recurrent oral ulcers and can also manifest with involvement of the eyes (uveitis and/or retinal vasculitis) and skin (erythema nodosum, papulopustular lesions, dermatographism).

E) INCORRECT:

A Giemsa-stained smear is used to detect Donovan bodies, which are pathognomonic for granuloma inguinale. This condition causes painless genital nodules that eventually ulcerate rather than painful vesicular lesions like the ones seen in this patient. Additionally, granuloma inguinale is not associated with tender inguinal lymphadenopathy and systemic symptoms, both of which are seen here.

Giemsa stain also forms part of the process of Tzanck smear, which is an option for rapid diagnosis of HSV infections. However, Tzanck smear has a low sensitivity and specificity and does not differentiate between HSV-1 and HSV-2. Another study is more appropriate to confirm the diagnosis in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

A perilesional punch biopsy is indicated for the diagnosis of autoimmune blistering disorders such as bullous pemphigoid and pemphigus vulgaris. These conditions can affect the genital area, but they typically cause blisters rather than vesicles. Tender inguinal lymphadenopathy is not expected in patients with these conditions. Finally, isolated genital involvement is uncommon.
questions.hint: Painful vesicular genital lesions in conjunction with bilateral tender inguinal lymphadenopathy should raise concern for genital herpes infection.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a 2-day history of painful mouth sores and fever. He is not able to eat any solid food because of the pain but tolerates liquids. He has had no nausea, vomiting, or skin rash. He has a history of asthma treated with inhaled fluticasone, and epilepsy that has been well controlled with lamotrigine since the age 13. There is no history of a similar illness among family members or his friends at school. He is at the 75th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 94/min, and blood pressure is 112/68 mm Hg. Examination shows dry mucous membranes. A photograph of the oral examination findings is shown. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lamotrigine can trigger Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS), which can manifest with painful oral vesicles, erosions, and fever. However, SJS typically develops shortly after initiation of lamotrigine therapy, rather than years later, and manifests with cutaneous (e.g., targetoid erythematous macules), ocular (e.g., conjunctivitis, corneal ulcers), and urogenital (e.g., urethritis, erosive vaginitis) features.
Image Description:

Widespread mucocutaneous necrosis with patches of complete epidermal destruction and involvement of the lips are visible.

These findings are suggestive for the SJS, which is triggered by pharmacological treatment (e.g., with antibiotics, antiepileptics).

B) INCORRECT:

Oral fluconazole therapy is used to treat oral candidiasis, which is a common adverse effect associated with the use of corticosteroid inhalers, and can cause discomfort when eating. However, oral candidiasis typically manifests with white pseudomembranes in the oral cavity as opposed to lip erosions and tongue vesicles, and fever is uncommon.
Image Description:

Yellow-white cottage cheese-like plaques are visible on the inflamed oropharyngeal mucosa.

These white plaques are pathognomonic of oral candidiasis (oral thrush), an opportunistic infection caused by Candida albicans.

C) CORRECT:

Oral acyclovir can be considered in immunocompetent patients with herpetic gingivostomatitis who are unable to eat or drink because of the severe pain caused by oral lesions. Some studies suggest that oral acyclovir decreases viral shedding, which decreases the duration and severity of infection when administered within 72 hours of symptom onset. Supportive care alone is indicated in patients who present > 72 hours after symptom onset. Antiviral therapy cannot treat latent infections or prevent disease recurrence. Additional treatment measures for herpetic gingivostomatitis include adequate hydration, analgesia, antipyretics, prevention of lip adhesions through barrier creams (e.g., petroleum jelly), and antibiotics for secondary bacterial infections.

Immunocompromised patients with herpetic gingivostomatitis should receive IV acyclovir regardless of symptom duration, and hospitalization may also be required.

D) INCORRECT:

Supportive care alone (i.e., adequate analgesia and fluid intake) is generally only considered in immunocompetent patients with herpetic gingivostomatitis who present > 4 days after symptom onset. Patients who present within 4 days of symptom onset benefit from treatment with an agent that decreases the duration and severity of infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Triamcinolone cream is used in the treatment of Behçet disease, which can manifest with painful oral lesions and fever. However, patients with Behçet disease typically develop aphthous ulcers, rather than oral vesicles, and usually present with genital ulcers, ocular disease (e.g., uveitis, keratitis), skin lesions (e.g., erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosum), and arthritis.
questions.hint: This patient's prodromal fever, dysphagia, and oral examination findings (lip erosions, vesicles over the tongue) suggest herpetic gingivostomatitis. Although herpetic gingivostomatitis is most common in young children 6 months to 5 years of age, it can also develop in older patients.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of an itchy and mildly painful rash on her vulva. Her symptoms have progressively worsened despite the use of over-the-counter antihistamines and topical corticosteroid cream. During the past week, she has also had headaches and muscle aches. Medical history is unremarkable. She is sexually active with multiple male partners. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. Her temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 107/68 mm Hg. Physical examination shows bilateral tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. A photograph of the genital area is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chancroid is a sexually transmitted infection, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, that can manifest with multiple anogenital ulcers and inguinal lymphadenopathy. However, chancroid ulcers are typically much larger in size (1–2 cm in diameter) than the small ulcers seen in this patient. Although chancroid ulcers can have an erythematous base, they are usually covered in gray-yellow exudates. In addition, chancroid ulcers are typically extremely painful, whereas this patient has reported only mild pain. Moreover, chancroid is extremely rare in the United States.
Image Description:

A small, red ulcer can be seen on the posterior vaginal wall (arrow). The pathogen that causes chancroid is Haemophilus ducreyi.

B) INCORRECT:

Lichen planus is a chronic inflammatory disease of unknown origin that classically manifests with pruritic, planar (flat-topped), polygonal, purple papules and plaques in individuals aged 30–60 years. This condition usually affects the extremities but can also affect the genitals. Although this patient's lesions are mildly pruritic, they do not have the classic morphological features of lichen planus.
Image Description:

Scattered, partially coalescent violaceous papules, macules, and plaques are visible on the shins.

C) CORRECT:

Genital herpes, a sexually transmitted infection caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV), particularly HSV-2, typically manifests with painful and/or pruritic vesicles in the anogenital region. These vesicles rupture easily, leaving punched out, erythematous ulcerations, as seen here. Primary infection with HSV is usually more severe and lasts longer than recurrent infection, and it often manifests with extragenital findings, including tender inguinal lymphadenopathy, dysuria, fever, and malaise. Although genital herpes is typically self-limited, antiviral drugs (e.g., acyclovir, valacyclovir) diminish the severity and duration of episodes and reduce viral shedding. Recurrence, which is caused by the reactivation of dormant virus in ganglion neurons, is common.

D) INCORRECT:

Syphilitic chancres, which are sexually transmitted and caused by Treponema pallidum, typically manifest with a firm ulcer with indurated borders and inguinal lymphadenopathy. However, chancres arise as a single painless ulcer rather than multiple painful and pruritic ulcers. Furthermore, the associated lymphadenopathy is usually nontender.
Image Description:

A round, ulcerative lesion with well-defined margins and a central induration is visible on the right labium majorum.

This finding is consistent with primary syphilitic chancre.

E) INCORRECT:

Lymphogranuloma venereum, a sexually transmitted infection caused by the L1–L3 serotypes of Chlamydia trachomatis, can manifest with multiple anogenital ulcers. However, these ulcers are characteristically painless and heal spontaneously within a few days. Lymphogranuloma venereum can cause inguinal lymphadenopathy, but it typically develops weeks after the primary infection.
Image Description:

Bilateral enlargement of the inguinal lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament is visible (groove sign).

The groove sign is characteristic of lymphogranuloma venereum, which is caused by acute Chlamydia trachomatis infection.
questions.hint: The photograph shows fluid-filled vesicles on erythematous bases in the vulvar and anal areas. Some of these vesicles have ruptured, resulting in erythematous ulcerations.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman with a history of periodic outbreaks of genital herpes presents with labial ulcerations. She has a history of documented infection with herpes simplex virus type 2 and has had an outbreak roughly once per year for the past 10 years. This year, however, she has had an outbreak every other month.
She is HIV-negative and has recently been sexually active with a new female partner, who does not have genital herpes. She is concerned about transmitting the virus to her partner.
Following treatment of this patient's current episode, which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for limiting transmission to an uninfected partner?

choices.text: Initiate oral valganciclovir as soon as any symptoms of recurrence surface
Complete a 10-day course of oral acyclovir

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Valganciclovir has antiviral activity against HSV (as well as against cytomegalovirus) but is not a first-line option because of its potential toxicity and the lack of need for a broadly active agent.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical acyclovir has no role as suppressive therapy for HSV.

C) INCORRECT:

Valganciclovir has antiviral activity against HSV (as well as against cytomegalovirus) but is not a first-line option because of its potential toxicity and the lack of need for a broadly active agent.

D) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection can be transmitted readily between sexual partners. Patients with frequent outbreaks of HSV, either type 1 or type 2, can opt for suppressive therapy. Oral acyclovir, famciclovir, and valacyclovir are all appropriate suppressive agents when used daily to prevent frequent outbreaks.

E) CORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection can be transmitted readily between sexual partners. Patients with frequent outbreaks of HSV, either type 1 or type 2, can opt for suppressive therapy. Oral acyclovir, famciclovir, and valacyclovir are all appropriate suppressive agents when used daily to prevent frequent outbreaks.

In this case, the patient has a second indication for suppressive therapy, namely a desire to prevent transmission to her seronegative sexual partner. Because subclinical viral shedding may occur in the absence of a visible ulceration, episodic therapy is much less effective than continuous suppressive treatment at reducing the number of risk days for transmission. Therefore, even in cases of less frequent outbreaks, suppressive therapy may be used in serodiscordant couples to prevent transmission to the unaffected partner.

Key learning point: The most effective therapy for reducing the likelihood that a patient with frequent outbreaks of herpes simplex virus will transmit the virus to an uninfected sexual partner is daily suppressive treatment with oral acyclovir, famciclovir, or valacyclovir.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents with a 3-day history of a mildly pruritic, slightly tender rash on her hands. She is otherwise healthy and reports no fevers, chills, conjunctival symptoms, or dysuria. She has a temperature of 37.7°C, a heart rate of 88 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 122/81 mm Hg, and a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute.
Skin examination reveals lesions on both palms (figure). In addition, she has a small, crusted healing lesion on her lower lip.
Which one of the following infections is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Secondary syphilis is often manifested by lesions on the palms, but they are usually ham-colored to violaceous macules, sometimes with a faint scaling, and lack the classic target appearance. The primary chancre is typically painless and can go unnoticed by the patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Human herpesvirus 6 reactivation is typically associated with fever; erythematous macules and papules on the trunk and extremities, extending to the face; facial edema; lymphadenopathy; and elevated aminotransferase levels.

C) INCORRECT:

Parvovirus infection rarely leads to rash in adults but when it does, it is typically a lacy reticulate rash on the thighs.

D) CORRECT:

Target-shaped lesions, which contain three distinct zones of color, are a classic presentation of erythema multiforme. In adults, up to 80% of cases of erythema multiforme are reactions to herpes simplex virus.

Key learning point: Target-shaped lesions on the palms may be a sign of erythema multiforme, which in adults is often associated with infection with herpes simplex virus.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with acute HIV seroconversion may develop a nonspecific exanthem of diffuse erythematous macules and papules, often with concurrent oral ulcerations. However, no target-shaped lesions would be present on the palms.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old male wrestler reports a 5-day history of a very tender rash on his forehead, cheek, ear, and neck. He had a low-grade fever on the day the rash started; the rash became vesicular and then crusted over during the past 2 days.
The patient is otherwise healthy, and his immunizations are up-to-date. He takes no medications and denies using any new foods or other products. He has never had a rash like this before.
He is afebrile and appears well. On his right temple, cheek, ear, and neck are clustered papules with surrounding erythema and overlying crust (figure).
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Impetigo, a bacterial infection most commonly caused by group A streptococcus or Staphylococcus aureus, manifests as weeping patches that quickly develop honey-colored crusts from dried pus (impetigo) or as cloudy fluid-filled vesicles or bullae (bullous impetigo). In adolescents, the lesions often develop on the face, particularly around the nose and mouth.

B) CORRECT:

Herpes gladiatorum, which is typically caused by herpes simplex virus type 1, is a common skin infection among wrestlers. It usually manifests as clusters of clear, fluid-filled blisters on an erythematous base that eventually crust over. The lesions spread readily by skin-to-skin contact and are highly contagious until they are completely crusted over. To prevent spread, athletes should not participate in wrestling while the eruption is in the vesicular stage. Like other herpes infections, these lesions may reactivate throughout life. Treatment with oral acyclovir, famciclovir, or valacyclovir should be considered to hasten healing of lesions.

Key learning point: In a wrestler with clusters of clear, fluid-filled blisters surrounded by erythema, the most likely diagnosis is herpes gladiatorum, which is most commonly caused by herpes simplex virus type 1.

C) INCORRECT:

Folliculitis, usually caused by skin bacteria, is an infection of the hair follicle. It results from damage to or blockage of the hair follicle. It manifests as a pimple, boil, or small abscess with a hair in the center. These lesions may be slightly pruritic or painful.

D) INCORRECT:

Molluscum contagiosum is a viral infection of the skin that is common among young children and adolescents and that is spread by close contact, such as during wrestling. Molluscum presents as individual, flesh-colored, umbilicated dome-shaped papules that become cloudy or red over time as the host’s immune system reacts to them.

E) INCORRECT:

Tinea corporis, a dermatophyte fungal infection, is highly contagious and can be transmitted by skin-to-skin contact and contact with contaminated items. Lesions typically appear as itchy, raised patches with scaly borders and relatively clear centers.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old college student who competes on his school wrestling team presents with painful pustular and vesicular skin eruptions. The symptoms started on his neck 5 days ago, at which time he was prescribed a course of cephalexin at a local urgent care clinic. He used the medication as instructed for 4 days but then discontinued it when he saw no improvement. He reports that the lesions initially caused only mild discomfort but have now become more painful and pruritic. He notes a history of atopic dermatitis but has otherwise been healthy without prior skin infection.
On examination, he appears well and is afebrile. He has scattered monomorphic, dome-shaped, 2-mm vesicles on an erythematous base on his neck extending to his right shoulder (figure). He also has vesicular lesions in his right antecubital fossa, where he had previously noted atopic dermatitis. He has no lymphadenopathy.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Prescribe triamcinolone ointment 0.1% to be applied to affected areas twice daily
Refer to the hospital for intravenous antibiotic administration

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical or oral glucocorticoids, such as triamcinolone or prednisone, can help to control underlying atopic dermatitis but should not be used in cases of active infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical or oral glucocorticoids, such as triamcinolone or prednisone, can help to control underlying atopic dermatitis but should not be used in cases of active infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole can be considered if a patient’s physical examination raises concern for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infection. However, this patient has no history of MRSA infection, and his vesicular lesions are indicative of HSV infection. Therefore, initiating a new antibiotic or administering intravenous antibiotics would not be beneficial.

D) CORRECT:

This patient’s painful vesicular lesions, history of atopic dermatitis, and lack of response to antibacterial therapy suggest a diagnosis of eczema herpeticum.

Eczema herpeticum is a disseminated superinfection of the skin caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV) in patients with atopic dermatitis. Patients with atopic dermatitis are prone to viral skin infection because of the impaired epidermal barrier and immune dysregulation associated with the dermatitis. The risk of infection increases with the severity of the dermatitis.

Eczema herpeticum is relatively rare, occurring in <3% of atopic dermatitis cases, and is more common in children than in adults. It manifests with sudden onset of painful, pruritic, monomorphic, dome-shaped vesicles on an erythematous base. These lesions develop on areas of preexisting atopic dermatitis — most commonly the face, neck, and upper torso — and can progress to involve normal skin within a week after onset. The vesicles can then rupture and form erosions that coalesce to form larger ulcerations. In some cases, the skin findings may resemble those of the bacterial infection impetigo. Systemic symptoms of fever, malaise, and lymphadenopathy may occur as the lesions progress.

Eczema herpeticum can be diagnosed clinically on the basis of examination findings and should be treated immediately to halt progression. The condition can be life-threatening if complications of systemic viremia or bacteremia develop. HSV polymerase chain-rection (PCR) testing, viral culture, or both can be performed on vesicle fluid for confirmation and determination of HSV type, but treatment should be initiated empirically while awaiting microbiologic results. Bacterial culture can be performed if there is concern for co-occurring bacterial infection.

This patient has a mild case of eczema herpeticum (i.e., limited skin findings and no systemic symptoms) and should therefore be treated with oral acyclovir or valacyclovir for 7 to 21 days or until all lesions are crusted over. He should not return to practice or competition until he has been on antiviral therapy for at least 5 days and all lesions have crusted over.

Patients with eczema herpeticum who have a more severe case or are immunocompromised should be hospitalized for intravenous acyclovir and other higher-level support as needed.

Patients with atopic dermatitis should be educated about the presenting signs and symptoms of superinfection and about when to seek medical attention. This education is particularly important for those who participate in activities like wrestling that carry a risk of exposure to skin-related disease.

Key learning point: Mild cases of eczema herpeticum are best treated with either oral acyclovir or valacyclovir.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient's vesicular lesions are indicative of HSV infection. Therefore, initiating a new antibiotic or administering intravenous antibiotics would not be beneficial. Patients with eczema herpeticum who have a more severe case or are immunocompromised should be hospitalized for intravenous acyclovir and other higher-level support as needed.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old male wrestler reports a 5-day history of a very tender rash on his forehead, cheek, ear, and neck. He had a low-grade fever on the day the rash started; the rash became vesicular and then crusted over during the past 2 days.
The patient is otherwise healthy, and his immunizations are up to date. He takes no medications and denies using any new foods or other products. He has never had a rash like this before.
He is afebrile and appears well. On his right temple, cheek, ear, and neck are clustered papules with surrounding erythema and overlying crust (figure).
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tinea corporis, a dermatophyte fungal infection, is highly contagious and can be transmitted by skin-to-skin contact and contact with contaminated items. Lesions typically appear as itchy, raised patches with scaly borders and relatively clear centers.

B) CORRECT:

Herpes gladiatorum, which is typically caused by herpes simplex virus type 1, is a common skin infection among wrestlers. It usually manifests as clusters of clear, fluid-filled blisters on an erythematous base that eventually crust over. The lesions spread readily by skin-to-skin contact and are highly contagious until they are completely crusted over. To prevent spread, athletes should not participate in wrestling while the eruption is in the vesicular stage. Like other herpes infections, these lesions may reactivate throughout life. Treatment with oral acyclovir, famciclovir, or valacyclovir should be considered to hasten healing of lesions.

Key learning point: In a teenage wrestler with clusters of clear, fluid-filled blisters surrounded by erythema, the most likely diagnosis is herpes gladiatorum, which is most commonly caused by herpes simplex virus type 1.

C) INCORRECT:

Folliculitis, usually caused by skin bacteria, is an infection of the hair follicle. It results from damage to or blockage of the hair follicle. It manifests as a pimple, boil, or small abscess with a hair in the center. These lesions may be slightly pruritic or painful.

D) INCORRECT:

Impetigo, a bacterial infection most commonly caused by group A streptococcus or Staphylococcus aureus, manifests as weeping patches that quickly develop honey-colored crusts from dried pus (impetigo) or as cloudy fluid-filled vesicles or bullae (bullous impetigo). In adolescents, the lesions often develop on the face, particularly around the nose and mouth.

E) INCORRECT:

Molluscum contagiosum is a viral infection of the skin that is common among young children and adolescents and that is spread by close contact, such as during wrestling. Molluscum presents as individual, flesh-colored, umbilicated dome-shaped papules that become cloudy or red over time as the host’s immune system reacts to them.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy with no significant medical history is evaluated for dehydration and refusal to eat or drink. Seven days ago, he developed a fever of 38.9°C, which resolved within 2 days. As the fever resolved, the child’s mother noticed fluid-filled bumps on his tongue and in his mouth. The bumps have spread and seem to be causing pain.
The child is currently afebrile with mild tachycardia for his age and a capillary refill of about 2 seconds. He has dry mucous membranes and halitosis. Many painful, shallow ulcerations are evident on his tongue, buccal mucosa, and gingiva with areas of crusting, and there is tender submandibular lymphadenopathy. The rest of his physical examination is unremarkable.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?

choices.text: Periodic fever, aphthous stomatitis, pharyngitis, and adenitis syndrome

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Periodic fever, aphthous stomatitis, pharyngitis, and adenitis syndrome (PFAPA) is a rheumatologic condition that is diagnosed on the basis of recurrent symptoms. Patients with PFAPA are typically preschool age (2–6 years) and present with high fevers that occur at 21- to 28-day intervals. The fever can be accompanied by the associated symptoms of aphthous stomatitis, pharyngitis, and cervical lymphadenitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Herpangina is a condition caused by coxsackie viruses. It can also be associated with fever, and, like herpetic gingivostomatitis, it involves oral vesicles, which ultimately rupture to form painful ulcerations. This illness typically resolves spontaneously within 3 to 5 days. Oral ulcerations from herpangina are more typically found in the posterior pharynx, not the lips and gums.

C) INCORRECT:

Hand, foot, and mouth disease is a condition caused by coxsackie viruses. It can also be associated with fever, and, like herpetic gingivostomatitis, it involves oral vesicles, which ultimately rupture to form painful ulcerations. This illness typically resolves spontaneously within 3 to 5 days. Hand, foot, and mouth disease would further be expected to involve eruptions on the hands and feet, as well as lesions in the posterior oropharynx. Lesions can also occur on the buttocks and extremities.

D) CORRECT:

Herpetic gingivostomatitis, which is typically caused by herpes simplex virus 1, can cause a prolonged illness like this patient’s. The condition typically manifests with a prodrome of fever, malaise, and anorexia, after which clusters of vesicles may form throughout the oral cavity. Submandibular lymphadenopathy is common. The ulcers often heal within a week, but in severe cases, they may persist for 2 to 3 weeks, causing some children to refuse to eat or drink and potentially leading to clinically significant dehydration. Oral acyclovir administered early in the course of the primary viral eruption can speed healing and reduce viral shedding.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of a febrile illness and an eruption of painful anterior oral vesicles with areas of crusting in a child who has been ill for a week and shows signs of dehydration is herpetic gingivostomatitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Benign aphthous ulcers may be painful but would not be associated with a febrile illness and typically would not lead to dehydration.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old boy who competes on his school wrestling team presents with painful pustular and vesicular skin eruptions. The symptoms started on his neck 5 days ago, at which time he was prescribed a course of cephalexin at a local urgent care clinic. He used the medication as instructed for 4 days but then discontinued it when he saw no improvement. He reports that the lesions initially caused only mild discomfort but have now become more painful and pruritic. He notes a history of atopic dermatitis but has otherwise been healthy without prior skin infection.
On examination, he appears well and is afebrile. He has scattered monomorphic, dome-shaped, 2-mm vesicles on an erythematous base on his neck extending to his right shoulder (figure). He also has vesicular lesions in his right antecubital fossa, where he had previously noted atopic dermatitis. He has no lymphadenopathy.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Refer to the hospital for intravenous antibiotic administration
Prescribe triamcinolone ointment 0.1% to be applied to affected areas twice daily

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient's vesicular lesions are indicative of HSV infection. Therefore, initiating a new antibiotic or administering intravenous antibiotics would not be beneficial. Patients with eczema herpeticum who have a more severe case or are immunocompromised should be hospitalized for intravenous acyclovir and other higher-level support as needed.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical or oral glucocorticoids, such as triamcinolone or prednisone, can help to control underlying atopic dermatitis but should not be used in cases of active infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole can be considered if a patient’s physical examination raises concern for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infection. However, this patient has no history of MRSA infection, and his vesicular lesions are indicative of HSV infection. Therefore, initiating a new antibiotic or administering intravenous antibiotics would not be beneficial.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical or oral glucocorticoids, such as triamcinolone or prednisone, can help to control underlying atopic dermatitis but should not be used in cases of active infection.

E) CORRECT:

This patient’s painful vesicular lesions, history of atopic dermatitis, and lack of response to antibacterial therapy suggest a diagnosis of eczema herpeticum.

Eczema herpeticum is a disseminated superinfection of the skin caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV) in patients with atopic dermatitis. Patients with atopic dermatitis are prone to viral skin infection because of the impaired epidermal barrier and immune dysregulation associated with the dermatitis. The risk of infection increases with the severity of the dermatitis.

Eczema herpeticum is relatively rare, occurring in <3% of atopic dermatitis cases, and is more common in children than in adults. It manifests with sudden onset of painful, pruritic, monomorphic, dome-shaped vesicles on an erythematous base. These lesions develop on areas of preexisting atopic dermatitis — most commonly the face, neck, and upper torso — and can progress to involve normal skin within a week after onset. The vesicles can then rupture and form erosions that coalesce to form larger ulcerations. In some cases, the skin findings may resemble those of the bacterial infection impetigo. Systemic symptoms of fever, malaise, and lymphadenopathy may occur as the lesions progress.

Eczema herpeticum can be diagnosed clinically on the basis of examination findings and should be treated immediately to halt progression. The condition can be life-threatening if complications of systemic viremia or bacteremia develop. HSV polymerase chain-rection (PCR) testing, viral culture, or both can be performed on vesicle fluid for confirmation and determination of HSV type, but treatment should be initiated empirically while awaiting microbiologic results. Bacterial culture can be performed if there is concern for co-occurring bacterial infection.

This patient has a mild case of eczema herpeticum (i.e., limited skin findings and no systemic symptoms) and should therefore be treated with oral acyclovir or valacyclovir for 7 to 21 days or until all lesions are crusted over. He should not return to practice or competition until he has been on antiviral therapy for at least 5 days and all lesions have crusted over.

Patients with eczema herpeticum who have a more severe case or are immunocompromised should be hospitalized for intravenous acyclovir and other higher-level support as needed.

Patients with atopic dermatitis should be educated about the presenting signs and symptoms of superinfection and about when to seek medical attention. This education is particularly important for those who participate in activities like wrestling that carry a risk of exposure to skin-related disease.

Key learning point: Mild cases of eczema herpeticum are best treated with either oral acyclovir or valacyclovir.

HEENT: normal oropharynx; pink and moist 
Pulmonary: clear lung fields
Cardiac: regular rhythm, no murmurs
Abdominal: soft and nontender; no organomegaly


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dermatitis herpetiformis is an IgA-mediated skin reaction that is associated with celiac disease and typically manifests as a pruritic, painful papulovesicular rash. However, this patient does not have a history of gluten sensitivity, malabsorption, or gastrointestinal symptoms. Moreover, targetoid skin lesions, which are seen in this patient, would not be expected.
Image Description:

Grouped, erythematous, papulovesicular lesions that are partially excoriated (presumably due to pruritus) can be seen on the dorsal forearm.

These findings, especially in combination with pruritus, suggest dermatitis herpetiformis.

B) INCORRECT:

Eczema herpeticum is a complication of atopic dermatitis caused by herpes simplex virus infection and typically manifests as a widespread rash with painful, vesicular lesions. This patient does not have a reported history of atopic dermatitis and the target lesions make this an unlikely diagnosis.
Image Description:

Multiple monomorphic, umbilicated, vesicular papules and punched-out erosions with hemorrhagic crusts are visible on the back of a young patient with a history of atopic eczema.

These findings are consistent with eczema herpeticum, a dermatological emergency requiring urgent evaluation and immediate antiviral therapy. Lesions located near the eyes require referral to ophthalmology due to the risk for corneal involvement.

C) CORRECT:

This patient with recurrent genital HSV and a painful exanthem with target lesions most likely has erythema multiforme (EM). EM is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction of the skin that can be triggered by certain infections (e.g., HSV, Mycoplasma pneumoniae) and medications (e.g., beta-lactam antibiotics, sulfonamides, phenytoin). EM is characterized by lesions of varying morphology (e.g., macules, papules, vesicles) that typically progress to target lesions and spread proximally from the backs of the hands and feet, as seen here. In EM minor, mucous membranes are not or only minimally involved while in EM major, mucosal involvement occurs. Nikolsky sign is negative and the disease course is self-limiting in most cases.
Image Description:

Multiple circular lesions with a central papule and raised edges (also called “target lesions”), surrounded by a lighter edematous area, are visible on the anterior aspect of the thighs.

This is the typical appearance of erythema multiforme.

D) INCORRECT:

Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) is a life-threatening type IV hypersensitivity reaction of the skin that can be triggered by certain medications (e.g., beta-lactam antibiotics, sulfonamides, lamotrigine) and infections (e.g., Mycoplasma pneumoniae). SJS can manifest with a painful rash with targetoid lesions, as seen in this patient. However, skin involvement in SJS is typically localized to the face and trunk. Moreover, this patient lacks other characteristic findings of SJS, such as high fever, epidermal detachment with a positive Nikolsky sign, skin necrosis, and involvement of mucous membranes.
Image Description:

Widespread mucocutaneous necrosis with patches of complete epidermal destruction and involvement of the lips are visible.

These findings are suggestive for the SJS, which is triggered by pharmacological treatment (e.g., with antibiotics, antiepileptics).

E) INCORRECT:

Urticaria (hives) is a type I hypersensitivity reaction that results from IgE-mediated mast cell degranulation. Urticaria is associated with certain medications (e.g., beta-lactam antibiotics) and infections (e.g., Mycoplasma pneumoniae) and typically manifests as a pruritic, raised erythematous rash. In contrast to the rash seen in this patient, urticaria is typically painless, well-circumscribed, and usually disappears after a few hours.
Image Description:

Multiple well-defined, erythematous, partially confluent lesions with raised serpiginous borders and central clearing are visible.

This is the characteristic appearance of urticaria, which typically has an acute onset, is highly pruritic, and transient.
questions.hint: This patient's rash is most commonly associated with herpes simplex infections and is characterized by target lesions (macules with a dusky center surrounded by a lighter ring).

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl presents with a recurrent rash around her mouth. She is a new patient who recently moved to the area and reports no other medical problems. Approximately once every other month, but without a predictable schedule, she suddenly develops a painful rash around her lips, which lasts for a total of 5 to 7 days and then resolves. This pattern has been recurring for more than a year. There are no preceding symptoms, and the rash is unrelated to her menstrual cycle, which occurs regularly every 30 days.
The patient has tried various over-the-counter topical therapies for the rash, including antibiotics, antifungals, anesthetics, and glucocorticoids, but nothing seems to help. She is very embarrassed and “stressed out” by these symptoms and feels they are preventing her from making friends in her new school. She reports no headache, fever, malaise, or other skin concerns. She has never been sexually active.
Her vital signs are stable. A complete physical examination is performed, including an external genitourinary examination, and is notable only for crusted vesicular lesions on the upper lip (figure).
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Oral acyclovir daily for 10 days, beginning at the start of each episode
Penciclovir 1% cream daily for 4 days, beginning at the start of each episode

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral tetracyclines, including doxycycline, are an option for the combination therapy of moderate and severe acne, which should be considered when evaluating dermatologic outbreaks. However, the perioral area is not typically affected, and acne manifests with papules and pustules, rather than painful vesicles with crusting. In addition, the relatively rapid appearance and disappearance of lesions is not characteristic of acne, especially if there is no association with the menstrual cycle.

Oral antibiotics may also be used to treat perioral dermatitis. This condition commonly affects young women and manifests with papules, and sometimes vesicles, around the mouth.
