The lesions may be painful. It can be exacerbated by exposure to topical steroids. However, in contrast to herpes labialis, perioral dermatitis typically spares the skin immediately adjacent to the lips, and is usually chronic rather than acute episodes.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical retinoids (e.g., tretinoin) may be used for acne, which should be considered when evaluating dermatologic outbreaks. However, the perioral area is not typically affected, and acne manifests with papules and pustules, rather than painful vesicles with crusting. In addition, the relatively rapid appearance and disappearance of lesions is not characteristic of acne, especially if there is no association with the menstrual cycle.

C) CORRECT:

This patient is experiencing very frequent outbreaks of herpes labialis, or cold sores, which are usually caused by herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1). HSV-1 infection is very common and is usually acquired during childhood. It is transmitted via oral secretions or contact with lesions, and primary infection can be asymptomatic or manifest with herpetic gingivostomatitis and systemic symptoms. After primary infection, the virus establishes latency in the trigeminal sensory ganglia and can intermittently reactivate. Reactivation manifests as herpes labialis and often occurs during times of physical or psychological stress. Ultraviolet light, menses, and acute infectious illnesses can also trigger reactivation.

Management options for herpes labialis include observation, topical anesthetics, intermittent oral antiviral therapy, and long-term suppressive oral antiviral therapy.

Long-term (> 1 month) suppressive oral antiviral therapy with daily acyclovir or valacyclovir is an appropriate option for patients with severe disease, frequent recurrences (approximately 6 or more episodes/year), no prodromal symptoms, and/or if outbreaks significantly affect quality of life.

This patient meets the criteria for long-term suppressive therapy. Suppressive therapy can reduce the number of HSV outbreaks, as well as their duration and severity. The need for suppressive therapy should be reassessed every year. Treating this patient episodically, while an option, will not reduce her frequent outbreaks. If episodic treatment is indicated (i.e., breakthrough of suppressive therapy), valacyclovir is the preferred antiviral, and a short course is recommended. Topical antivirals have limited use in the treatment of recurrent herpes labialis.

Key learning point: In patients with herpes labialis who experience severe or frequent recurrences, especially if there is no clear prodrome, the most appropriate treatment is long-term suppressive oral antiviral therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Treating this patient episodically, while an option, will not reduce her frequent outbreaks. If episodic treatment is indicated (i.e., breakthrough of suppressive therapy), valacyclovir is the preferred antiviral, and a shorter duration (5 days) is recommended.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical antivirals, including acyclovir and penciclovir, may be used for occasional episodes of mild herpes labialis. However, their benefit is limited and inferior to that of oral therapy. Topical antivirals have limited use in the treatment of recurrent herpes labialis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a recurrent vesicular genital rash comes to the office because of a 3-day history of a painful, pruritic rash that began on the extremities and has spread to her trunk. Her only medication is acyclovir. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F). Examination of the skin shows several reddish-purple papules and macules, some of which have a dusky center with a lighter ring around them. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Eczema herpeticum is a complication of atopic dermatitis caused by herpes simplex virus infection and typically manifests as a widespread rash with painful, vesicular lesions. This patient does not have a reported history of atopic dermatitis and the target lesions make this an unlikely diagnosis.
Image Description:

Multiple monomorphic, umbilicated, vesicular papules and punched-out erosions with hemorrhagic crusts are visible on the back of a young patient with a history of atopic eczema.

These findings are consistent with eczema herpeticum, a dermatological emergency requiring urgent evaluation and immediate antiviral therapy. Lesions located near the eyes require referral to ophthalmology due to the risk for corneal involvement.

B) CORRECT:

This patient with recurrent genital HSV and a painful exanthem with target lesions most likely has erythema multiforme (EM). EM is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction of the skin that can be triggered by certain infections (e.g., HSV, Mycoplasma pneumoniae) and medications (e.g., beta-lactam antibiotics, sulfonamides, phenytoin). EM is characterized by lesions of varying morphology (e.g., macules, papules, vesicles) that typically progress to target lesions and spread proximally from the backs of the hands and feet, as seen here. In EM minor, mucous membranes are not or only minimally involved while in EM major, mucosal involvement occurs. Nikolsky sign is negative and the disease course is self-limiting in most cases.
Image Description:

Multiple circular lesions with a central papule and raised edges (also called “target lesions”), surrounded by a lighter edematous area, are visible on the anterior aspect of the thighs.

This is the typical appearance of erythema multiforme.

C) INCORRECT:

Urticaria (hives) is a type I hypersensitivity reaction that results from IgE-mediated mast cell degranulation. Urticaria is associated with certain medications (e.g., beta-lactam antibiotics) and infections (e.g., Mycoplasma pneumoniae) and typically manifests as a pruritic, raised erythematous rash. In contrast to the rash seen in this patient, urticaria is typically painless, well-circumscribed, and usually disappears after a few hours.
Image Description:

Multiple well-defined, erythematous, partially confluent lesions with raised serpiginous borders and central clearing are visible.

This is the characteristic appearance of urticaria, which typically has an acute onset, is highly pruritic, and transient.

D) INCORRECT:

Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) is a life-threatening type IV hypersensitivity reaction of the skin that can be triggered by certain medications (e.g., beta-lactam antibiotics, sulfonamides, lamotrigine) and infections (e.g., Mycoplasma pneumoniae). SJS can manifest with a painful rash with targetoid lesions, as seen in this patient. However, skin involvement in SJS is typically localized to the face and trunk. Moreover, this patient lacks other characteristic findings of SJS, such as high fever, epidermal detachment with a positive Nikolsky sign, skin necrosis, and involvement of mucous membranes.
Image Description:

Widespread mucocutaneous necrosis with patches of complete epidermal destruction and involvement of the lips are visible.

These findings are suggestive for the SJS, which is triggered by pharmacological treatment (e.g., with antibiotics, antiepileptics).

E) INCORRECT:

Dermatitis herpetiformis is an IgA-mediated skin reaction that is associated with celiac disease and typically manifests as a pruritic, painful papulovesicular rash. However, this patient does not have a history of gluten sensitivity, malabsorption, or gastrointestinal symptoms. Moreover, targetoid skin lesions, which are seen in this patient, would not be expected.
Image Description:

Grouped, erythematous, papulovesicular lesions that are partially excoriated (presumably due to pruritus) can be seen on the dorsal forearm.

These findings, especially in combination with pruritus, suggest dermatitis herpetiformis.
questions.hint: This patient's rash is most commonly associated with herpes simplex infections and is characterized by target lesions (macules with a dusky center surrounded by a lighter ring).

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 1-week history of an itchy and mildly painful rash on her vulva. Her symptoms have progressively worsened despite the use of over-the-counter antihistamines and topical corticosteroid cream. During the past week, she has also had headaches and muscle aches. Medical history is unremarkable. She is sexually active with multiple male partners. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. Her temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 107/68 mm Hg. Physical examination shows bilateral tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. A photograph of the genital area is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chancroid is a sexually transmitted infection, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, that can manifest with multiple anogenital ulcers and inguinal lymphadenopathy. However, chancroid ulcers are typically much larger in size (1–2 cm in diameter) than the small ulcers seen in this patient. Although chancroid ulcers can have an erythematous base, they are usually covered in gray-yellow exudates. In addition, chancroid ulcers are typically extremely painful, whereas this patient has reported only mild pain. Moreover, chancroid is extremely rare in the United States.
Image Description:

A small, red ulcer can be seen on the posterior vaginal wall (arrow). The pathogen that causes chancroid is Haemophilus ducreyi.

B) INCORRECT:

Lichen planus is a chronic inflammatory disease of unknown origin that classically manifests with pruritic, planar (flat-topped), polygonal, purple papules and plaques in individuals aged 30–60 years. This condition usually affects the extremities but can also affect the genitals. Although this patient's lesions are mildly pruritic, they do not have the classic morphological features of lichen planus.
Image Description:

Scattered, partially coalescent violaceous papules, macules, and plaques are visible on the shins.

C) CORRECT:

Genital herpes, a sexually transmitted infection caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV), particularly HSV-2, typically manifests with painful and/or pruritic vesicles in the anogenital region. These vesicles rupture easily, leaving punched out, erythematous ulcerations, as seen here. Primary infection with HSV is usually more severe and lasts longer than recurrent infection, and it often manifests with extragenital findings, including tender inguinal lymphadenopathy, dysuria, fever, and malaise. Although genital herpes is typically self-limited, antiviral drugs (e.g., acyclovir, valacyclovir) diminish the severity and duration of episodes and reduce viral shedding. Recurrence, which is caused by the reactivation of dormant virus in ganglion neurons, is common.

D) INCORRECT:

Syphilitic chancres, which are sexually transmitted and caused by Treponema pallidum, typically manifest with a firm ulcer with indurated borders and inguinal lymphadenopathy. However, chancres arise as a single painless ulcer rather than multiple painful and pruritic ulcers. Furthermore, the associated lymphadenopathy is usually nontender.
Image Description:

A round, ulcerative lesion with well-defined margins and a central induration is visible on the right labium majorum.

This finding is consistent with primary syphilitic chancre.

E) INCORRECT:

Lymphogranuloma venereum, a sexually transmitted infection caused by the L1–L3 serotypes of Chlamydia trachomatis, can manifest with multiple anogenital ulcers. However, these ulcers are characteristically painless and heal spontaneously within a few days. Lymphogranuloma venereum can cause inguinal lymphadenopathy, but it typically develops weeks after the primary infection.
Image Description:

Bilateral enlargement of the inguinal lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament is visible (groove sign).

The groove sign is characteristic of lymphogranuloma venereum, which is caused by acute Chlamydia trachomatis infection.
questions.hint: The photograph shows fluid-filled vesicles on erythematous bases in the vulvar and anal areas. Some of these vesicles have ruptured, resulting in erythematous ulcerations.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the office because of a 3-day history of groin pain. Yesterday, he noticed painful vesicles on his penis, which he has never had before. He is sexually active with multiple male and female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. He has no family history of serious illness. He appears ill and uncomfortable. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 134/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows tender inguinal lymphadenopathy bilaterally. There are multiple grouped vesicular lesions with underlying erythema on the base of the penis. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Serological antibody test differentiates between HSV-1 and HSV-2. This test is not used in active, primary genital herpes infections because patients may present before seroconversion. Serological antibody testing is indicated in patients with a history of genital vesicular lesions who have had a negative real-time PCR or viral culture or who have a sexual partner with a known HSV infection. Furthermore, serologic antibody testing is indicated in pregnant women with an active genital lesion to classify the maternal infection as primary or nonprimary and to determine the HSV subtype, because these criteria are important for the prognostication of vertical transmission to the infant.

B) CORRECT:

Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) is the preferred confirmatory diagnostic test for HSV infection. Other diagnostic tests include viral culture, which has lower sensitivity than PCR but can also confirm HSV infection, especially in the early stages of infection when fresh vesicular lesions are present. Serum antibody testing is another diagnostic test for HSV infection, but it cannot be used for primary infections because specific antibodies only develop following seroconversion. Tzanck smear is no longer used for diagnosing HSV infections because it has a low sensitivity and specificity and does not differentiate between HSV-1 and HSV-2.

C) INCORRECT:

Darkfield microscopy is used to detect Treponema pallidum in primary and secondary syphilis when specimens can be obtained from skin lesions (e.g., primary genital lesion, condyloma). Primary syphilis causes genital lesions that are typically single, painless ulcers with indurated borders rather than painful vesicular lesions like the ones seen in this patient. Additionally, patients with primary syphilis develop nontender rather than painful inguinal lymphadenopathy and usually do not have systemic symptoms such as fever and malaise.

D) INCORRECT:

A Giemsa-stained smear is used to detect Donovan bodies, which are pathognomonic for granuloma inguinale. This condition causes painless genital nodules that eventually ulcerate rather than painful vesicular lesions like the ones seen in this patient. Additionally, granuloma inguinale is not associated with tender inguinal lymphadenopathy and systemic symptoms, both of which are seen here.

Giemsa stain also forms part of the process of Tzanck smear, which is an option for rapid diagnosis of HSV infections. However, Tzanck smear has a low sensitivity and specificity and does not differentiate between HSV-1 and HSV-2. Another study is more appropriate to confirm the diagnosis in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

A perilesional punch biopsy is indicated for the diagnosis of autoimmune blistering disorders such as bullous pemphigoid and pemphigus vulgaris. These conditions can affect the genital area, but they typically cause blisters rather than vesicles. Tender inguinal lymphadenopathy is not expected in patients with these conditions. Finally, isolated genital involvement is uncommon.
questions.hint: Painful vesicular genital lesions in conjunction with bilateral tender inguinal lymphadenopathy should raise concern for genital herpes infection.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male wrestler reports a 5-day history of a very tender rash on his face and neck. He had a low-grade fever on the day the rash started; the rash became vesicular and then crusted over during the past 2 days. He is afebrile and appears well. On his right temple, cheek, ear, and neck are clustered papules with surrounding erythema and overlying crust (figure). What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Impetigo, a bacterial infection most commonly caused by group A streptococcus or Staphylococcus aureus, manifests as weeping patches that quickly develop honey-colored crusts from dried pus (impetigo) or as cloudy fluid-filled vesicles or bullae (bullous impetigo). In adolescents, the lesions often develop on the face, particularly around the nose and mouth.

B) CORRECT:

Herpes gladiatorum, which is typically caused by herpes simplex virus type 1, is a common skin infection among wrestlers. It usually manifests as clusters of clear, fluid-filled blisters on an erythematous base that eventually crust over. The lesions spread readily by skin-to-skin contact and are highly contagious until they are completely crusted over. To prevent spread, athletes should not participate in wrestling while the eruption is in the vesicular stage. Like other herpes infections, these lesions may reactivate throughout life. Treatment with oral acyclovir, famciclovir, or valacyclovir should be considered to hasten healing of lesions.

Key learning point: In a wrestler with clusters of clear, fluid-filled blisters surrounded by erythema, the most likely diagnosis is herpes gladiatorum, which is most commonly caused by herpes simplex virus type 1.

C) INCORRECT:

Folliculitis, usually caused by skin bacteria, is an infection of the hair follicle. It results from damage to or blockage of the hair follicle. It manifests as a pimple, boil, or small abscess with a hair in the center. These lesions may be slightly pruritic or painful.

D) INCORRECT:

Molluscum contagiosum is a viral infection of the skin that is common among young children and adolescents and that is spread by close contact, such as during wrestling. Molluscum presents as individual, flesh-colored, umbilicated dome-shaped papules that become cloudy or red over time as the host’s immune system reacts to them.

E) INCORRECT:

Tinea corporis, a dermatophyte fungal infection, is highly contagious and can be transmitted by skin-to-skin contact and contact with contaminated items. Lesions typically appear as itchy, raised patches with scaly borders and relatively clear centers.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the office because of fever, malaise, and a painful, itchy rash on the right shoulder for 2 weeks. The patient's mother says the boy's condition has worsened over the past 4 days. He has a history of atopic dermatitis. He has lived with his mother at several public shelters since she separated from his physically abusive father 2 months ago. His immunizations are up-to-date. There is cervical lymphadenopathy. Laboratory studies show no abnormalities. A photograph of the rash is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Crowded living conditions are a risk factor for bed bug infestations. However, bed bug bites take the form of painless papules that becomes itchy and resolve spontaneously within a week. They are typically found on skin that is exposed during sleep.
Image Description:

Numerous macules and papules, both isolated and in clusters, are visible on the back.

While this finding is typical of bedbug bites, similar symptoms can appear in a wide variety of cutaneous reactions.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's symptoms (fever, malaise, lymphadenopathy) and his rash indicate eczema herpeticum, a cutaneous manifestation of herpes infection (usually HSV-1 or HSV-2). This condition is associated with pre-existing skin conditions, most often atopic dermatitis. Eczema herpeticum is considered a dermatological emergency because the rash on the patient's shoulder can disseminate rapidly. Treatment with oral or IV acyclovir should be initiated as soon as possible.

C) INCORRECT:

Shingles is associated with a rash in a dermatomal distribution, typically affecting 1–3 dermatomes on one side of the body. Most patients report severe burning or throbbing pain that is followed by a rash. The rash is initially maculopapular on an erythematous base and quickly progresses to a vesicular rash. Crusting and involution typically occur after 7–10 days. This patient's immunizations are up-to-date and should include the chickenpox vaccine.
Image Description:

Left arm of a child showing multiple, uniform vesicles on an erythematous base. The dermatomal distribution (C8 and T1) is characteristic of shingles. Patients complain of severe pain prior to the appearance of lesions.

D) INCORRECT:

Scabies typically affects the interdigital folds, wrists, and ankles, and patients classically have intense pruritus that is worst at night. Although crowded, unsanitary living conditions are a risk factor for this condition, the rash associated with scabies is not painful. Moreover, fever, malaise, and lymphadenopathy are not expected.
Image Description:

Multiple erythematous papules (partially excoriated) are visible in the interdigital folds and on the dorsal aspect of the hand and fingers.

E) INCORRECT:

Chickenpox is a highly contagious viral illness that typically manifests with a widespread, pruritic rash that initially involves the trunk and quickly spreads to the face, scalp, and extremities. This patient's underlying skin condition puts him at an increased risk of developing a severe form of chickenpox and complications such as bacterial superinfection and scarring. However, his immunizations are up-to-date and should include the chickenpox vaccine.
questions.hint: This patient's condition is also known as Kaposi varicelliform eruption.

questions.text: A 15-month-old girl is brought to the office because of a 2-day history of low-grade fever and a painful lesion on her left middle finger. She was born at term and has been healthy except for a vesicular rash on her upper lip 2 weeks ago, which resolved without treatment. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. A photograph of the left middle finger is shown. Physical examination shows tender left epitrochlear lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Human papillomavirus type 1 (HPV type 1) is a common cause of verruca vulgaris, also known as common warts. These typically present on the hands and feet as scaly papules, and are usually painless, though they may be pruritic. Since systemic symptoms and lymphadenopathy do not occur in verruca vulgaris, an infection with HPV type 1 can be ruled out.
Image Description:

Partially confluent, hyperkeratotic papules with a rough surface are seen on the dorsal surface of the hand at the level of the metacarpophalangeal joint

B) INCORRECT:

Group A Streptococcus (GAS) causes nonbullous impetigo, which can manifest with small vesicles surrounded by erythema and regional lymphadenopathy. However, this patient's history of a vesicular rash on the upper lip two weeks ago and the presence of systemic symptoms (i.e., fever) make a different condition more likely.

C) CORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) is the most common cause of herpetic whitlow, an infection of the dermal and subcutaneous tissue of the fingers (especially the thumb and index fingers). It is transmitted through direct contact between a break in the skin on the finger and infected secretions, often from primary oral lesions (e.g., labial herpes), as suggested in this patient. Children who suck their fingers and health care workers (especially dentists) are most commonly affected. The condition presents with painful, grouped, nonpurulent vesicles, usually accompanied by tingling, and burning sensations in the affected digits. Axillary and epitrochlear lymphadenopathy may also develop.

D) INCORRECT:

Molluscum contagiosum virus causes localized skin infection and is transmitted through direct skin contact with an infected individual. The lesions are usually painless, flesh-colored, and characteristically dome-shaped with a central umbilication. Typical predilection sites in children are the face, trunk, and extremities. This patient has no history of exposure to an infected individual and her lesions are very different from the lesions of molluscum contagiosum.
Image Description:

Several singular and partially confluent papules with central umbilication are visible at the lateral orbital rim.

These features are characteristic of molluscum contagiosum due to infection with molluscum contagiosum virus (poxvirus).

E) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of acute paronychia, a painful soft tissue infection affecting the skin around the nails of fingers and toes. Paronychia is typically purulent, unlike the skin lesion seen in this child, which suggests a nonbacterial etiology.
Image Description:

Periungual erythema, swelling, and pus proximal to the nail are characteristic findings of paronychia, in this case caused by Candida.
questions.hint: A Tzanck smear of the vesicular base will show multinucleated giant cells.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl comes to the office with a 4-day history of painful vulvar lesions, generalized fatigue, and malaise. During this period, she has also had dysuria. She is sexually active with 2 male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Her immunizations are up-to-date; she completed the vaccination course for human papillomavirus 2 months ago. Temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F). Pelvic examination shows several shallow ulcers on an erythematous base over the labia majora and minora. The ulcers are 1–3 mm in diameter. There is bilateral, tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A presentation of primary genital herpes in an otherwise healthy adolescent warrants prompt initiation of antiviral therapy with oral acyclovir, famciclovir, or valacyclovir for 7–10 days. This antiviral therapy reduces the duration and severity of infection as well as viral shedding, with maximal effect if begun within 72 hours of symptom onset. It does not, however, decrease the risk of latent infection or recurrence. Subsequent outbreaks are managed with episodic (on-demand) antiviral therapy for two days (started ideally within 24 hours of symptom onset). Daily suppressive therapy to decrease the risk of recurrence (antiviral therapy for up to a year) is reserved for patients experiencing frequent recurrences (≥ 6 in a year).

See “Overview of sexually transmitted genital lesions” table.
Image Description:

Photograph of the anogenital region of an adult female patient

Fluid-filled vesicles on erythematous bases are visible around the anus and vulva. Some of these vesicles have ruptured, leaving erythematous ulcerations.

These findings are consistent with herpes genitalis, most likely caused by infection with herpes simplex virus type 2.

B) INCORRECT:

Curettage is used to treat warts (caused by human papillomavirus) but not genital herpes. Genital warts can be transmitted sexually but present as painless papular growths and are not associated with tender lymphadenopathy, multiple painful shallow ulcers, or malaise, making this diagnosis very unlikely. Additionally, if this patient received a tetravalent or 9-valent vaccine regimen prior to potential infection, she would likely be immune to the HPV types (primarily 6 and 11) that cause genital warts.

C) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin is commonly used in the treatment of sexually transmitted infections such as chlamydia and chancroid. Chlamydia infection is commonly asymptomatic. Symptomatic patients typically present with pelvic pain, not skin lesions and lymphadenopathy. Chancroid is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi and manifests with multiple painful papules or pustules that erode into ulcers. Chancroid ulcers are usually larger (10–20 mm) and deeper than the ones seen here, and they have a greyish necrotic base and purulent exudate.

D) INCORRECT:

Doxycycline can be used to treat both syphilitic and chlamydial infections but not genital herpes. L1–L3 serotypes of Chlamydia trachomatis cause lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV), which manifests initially with a painless papule that resolves and then causes suppurative lymphadenopathy 2–6 weeks later. Treponema pallidum is responsible for syphilis, which manifests in the primary stage as a painless ulcer with nontender lymphadenopathy. Neither syphilis nor LGV are associated with multiple painful shallow ulcers, making them unlikely diagnoses.

E) INCORRECT:

Benzathine penicillin is effective against Treponema pallidum, the causative agent of syphilis. The primary stage of syphilis presents as a painless round ulcer called chancre that is typically a solitary lesion but can occasionally present with multiple lesions or bilateral lymphadenopathy. However, the lesion is generally painless.
questions.hint: The presence of several shallow ulcers on an erythematous base and bilateral tender inguinal lymphadenopathy in an individual with high-risk sexual behavior is indicative of genital herpes, which is diagnosed by performing a polymerase chain reaction test or viral culture on a smear obtained from the ulcer.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with a 2-day history of fever, irritability, and refusal to eat. Physical examination shows clusters of small, fluid-filled lesions around his lips and on his gums, which have eroded into painful ulcers. He has swollen, tender lymph nodes in the neck. No lesions are noted on his hands or feet.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hand-foot-and-mouth disease presents with fever and oral lesions, but it is characterized by vesicular or papulovesicular lesions on the hands, feet, and sometimes buttocks. The absence of lesions on the hands and feet in this patient contradicts the expected findings for this condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Herpangina, often caused by coxsackievirus, presents with fever and vesicular lesions on the posterior oropharynx, such as the soft palate and tonsillar pillars. The lesions in this patient are located around the lips and gingiva, which is inconsistent with herpangina's typical distribution.

C) CORRECT:

Acute herpetic gingivostomatitis is a primary infection with herpes simplex virus type 1, commonly affecting young children. It manifests with fever, irritability, and clusters of vesicular lesions around the lips and gingiva, which rapidly progress to painful ulcers. The condition also involves cervical lymphadenopathy due to the immune response to the localized mucosal infection. The combination of systemic symptoms and specific oral lesions distinguishes it from other oral conditions.

Key learning point: Primary herpes simplex virus infection in children often presents with fever, vesicular lesions around the mouth and gums, and cervical lymphadenopathy, known as gingivostomatitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Aphthous ulcers, or canker sores, typically present as single or few shallow ulcers on nonkeratinized mucosal surfaces without a preceding vesicular stage. They do not cause systemic symptoms like fever or cervical lymphadenopathy, which are indicative of an infectious process.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy presents with a 2-day history of fever, irritability, and refusal to eat. He is otherwise healthy. In the clinic, he appears uncomfortable and cries when attempting to swallow. Examination reveals multiple small fluid-filled lesions with a red base on his lips, gingiva, and anterior oral mucosa, and mildly enlarged cervical lymph nodes.

Temperature
38.3°C

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Primary herpetic gingivostomatitis is common in young children experiencing their first herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) infection. It manifests with acute fever, irritability, and painful vesicular lesions on the anterior oral mucosa, gingiva, and lips. These lesions evolve into ulcers and are often accompanied by cervical lymphadenopathy due to local inflammation. The symptoms of fever, irritability, and refusal to eat due to painful swallowing align with primary HSV-1 infection. Recognizing the lesion distribution and evolution in this age group is crucial for diagnosis.

Key learning point: Primary herpes simplex virus infection in young children often presents as gingivostomatitis with fever, sore throat, and characteristic oral lesions.

B) INCORRECT:

Hand-foot-and-mouth disease involves oral vesicles and lesions on the hands, feet, and sometimes buttocks. The absence of cutaneous lesions on the extremities in this child makes this diagnosis unlikely. The localized oral lesions and systemic symptoms suggest a different condition.

C) INCORRECT:

Herpangina, caused by Coxsackie A viruses, presents with vesicular lesions in the posterior oropharynx, such as the soft palate and uvula. The lesions in this child are on the lips, gingiva, and anterior oral mucosa, which is inconsistent with herpangina's typical lesion distribution.

D) INCORRECT:

Aphthous stomatitis presents as small, round ulcers with a gray or yellow center and an erythematous halo, not vesicular lesions. It typically causes localized oral discomfort without systemic symptoms. The presence of fever, irritability, and fluid-filled lesions in this child suggests a viral infection rather than aphthous stomatitis.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with a 2-day history of high fever, refusal to eat, and excessive drooling. His parents confirm he has not experienced a similar episode in the past. On examination, numerous small vesicles are seen on his lips and gingiva, some of which have ruptured into painful ulcers. The gums appear swollen and erythematous, and the child is irritable. There are no lesions on his hands or feet.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Herpangina causes fever and painful vesiculoulcerative lesions in children, but these lesions are typically localized to the posterior oropharynx, such as the soft palate and tonsillar pillars. The presence of lesions on the lips and gingiva, along with gingival erythema and swelling, is inconsistent with herpangina's typical anatomical distribution.

B) INCORRECT:

Aphthous stomatitis is characterized by small, shallow ulcers on non-keratinized mucosal surfaces without preceding vesicular lesions. It is typically idiopathic and recurrent, lacking systemic symptoms like high fever or excessive drooling. The presence of numerous vesicular lesions and systemic symptoms is inconsistent with aphthous stomatitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Hand-foot-and-mouth disease presents with oral lesions and characteristic involvement of the hands and feet. The absence of lesions on the palms and soles makes this diagnosis unlikely. The presence of painful oral vesicles and ulcers, with gingival inflammation, does not align with the expected pattern of this disease.

D) CORRECT:

Primary herpetic gingivostomatitis manifests in young children as a first exposure to herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1). Symptoms include high fever, refusal to eat, and excessive drooling, indicating systemic and oropharyngeal involvement. Oral examination reveals small vesicles on the lips and gingiva that progress to painful ulcers, reflecting HSV-1's cytopathic effects. Pronounced gingival inflammation, with swelling and erythema, indicates a robust immune response during primary infection. These clinical features are characteristic of an initial HSV-1 infection in a nonimmune host.

Key learning point: Primary herpetic gingivostomatitis in children is most commonly caused by Herpes Simplex Virus type 1, presenting with painful vesicular lesions in the oral cavity.

questions.text:
An 18-month-old boy is brought to the Emergency Department with a two-day history of high fever, irritability, and refusal to eat or drink. He appears dehydrated, with dry mucous membranes and decreased urine output. Physical examination reveals clusters of small vesicles and ulcerations on the gingiva, lips, and tongue. He cries in pain when his mouth is examined.


Heart rate
120/min


Blood pressure
90/60 mm Hg


Temperature
38.9°C


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The presentation of oral vesicles and ulcerations with fever suggests a viral etiology, such as primary herpetic gingivostomatitis, not a bacterial infection. Broad-spectrum antibiotics target bacteria and are ineffective against viruses, exposing the patient to unnecessary risks without addressing the underlying viral infection.

B) CORRECT:

Primary herpetic gingivostomatitis, caused by herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1), manifests with painful oral vesicles and ulcerations, leading to decreased oral intake. Early acyclovir administration, ideally within 72 hours, inhibits viral replication, reducing symptom severity and duration. Supportive hydration is crucial due to dehydration from reduced intake. This combined approach addresses viral inhibition and fluid balance restoration, essential in managing this condition in children.

Key learning point: In cases of primary herpetic gingivostomatitis in children, management should include antiviral therapy with acyclovir and supportive care such as intravenous fluids to address dehydration due to poor oral intake.

C) INCORRECT:

Intravenous immunoglobulins are used for immunologic or autoimmune conditions, not for viral infections like primary herpetic gingivostomatitis. The child's symptoms indicate a self-limited viral infection, best managed with supportive care, including hydration and pain control, rather than immunomodulatory therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical anesthetics provide temporary pain relief but do not address dehydration or systemic symptoms. The child requires comprehensive care, including fluid replacement, due to significant dehydration from reduced oral intake. Relying solely on topical anesthetics neglects the need for systemic support and hydration.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a history of recurrent vesicular genital rash comes to your clinic with a 3-day history of a painful, pruritic rash that started on her extremities and has now spread to her trunk. Her only medication is acyclovir. Her temperature is 38.1°C. On skin examination, you observe several reddish-purple papules and macules, some with a dusky center and a lighter ring surrounding them. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Urticaria (hives) is a type I hypersensitivity reaction that results from IgE-mediated mast cell degranulation. Urticaria is associated with certain medications (e.g., beta-lactam antibiotics) and infections (e.g., Mycoplasma pneumoniae) and typically manifests as a pruritic, raised erythematous rash. In contrast to the rash seen in this patient, urticaria is typically painless, well-circumscribed, and usually disappears after a few hours.

B) INCORRECT:

Eczema herpeticum is a complication of atopic dermatitis caused by herpes simplex virus infection and typically manifests as a widespread rash with painful, vesicular lesions. This patient does not have a reported history of atopic dermatitis and the target lesions make this an unlikely diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) is a life-threatening type IV hypersensitivity reaction of the skin that can be triggered by certain medications (e.g., beta-lactam antibiotics, sulfonamides, lamotrigine) and infections (e.g., Mycoplasma pneumoniae). SJS can manifest with a painful rash with targetoid lesions, as seen in this patient. However, skin involvement in SJS is typically localized to the face and trunk. Moreover, this patient lacks other characteristic findings of SJS, such as high fever, epidermal detachment with a positive Nikolsky sign, skin necrosis, and involvement of mucous membranes.

D) CORRECT:

This patient with recurrent genital HSV and a painful exanthem with target lesions most likely has erythema multiforme (EM). EM is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction of the skin that can be triggered by certain infections (e.g., HSV, Mycoplasma pneumoniae) and medications (e.g., beta-lactam antibiotics, sulfonamides, phenytoin). EM is characterized by lesions of varying morphology (e.g., macules, papules, vesicles) that typically progress to target lesions and spread proximally from the backs of the hands and feet, as seen here. In EM minor, mucous membranes are not or only minimally involved while in EM major, mucosal involvement occurs. Nikolsky sign is negative and the disease course is self-limiting in most cases.

Key learning point: Erythema multiforme is a self-limited, type IV hypersensitivity reaction characterized by target lesions that often follow infections like herpes simplex virus.
Image Description:

Multiple circular lesions with a central papule and raised edges (also called “target lesions”), surrounded by a lighter edematous area, are visible on the anterior aspect of the thighs.

This is the typical appearance of erythema multiforme.

E) INCORRECT:

Dermatitis herpetiformis is an IgA-mediated skin reaction that is associated with celiac disease and typically manifests as a pruritic, painful papulovesicular rash. However, this patient does not have a history of gluten sensitivity, malabsorption, or gastrointestinal symptoms. Moreover, targetoid skin lesions, which are seen in this patient, would not be expected.
questions.hint: This patient's rash is most commonly associated with herpes simplex infections and is characterized by target lesions (macules with a dusky center surrounded by a lighter ring).

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 1-week history of an itchy and mildly painful rash on her vulva. Her symptoms have progressively worsened despite using over-the-counter antihistamines and topical corticosteroid cream. Over the past week, she has also experienced headaches and muscle aches. Her medical history is unremarkable. She is sexually active with multiple male partners. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her temperature is 37.9°C, pulse is 85/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 107/68 mm Hg. On examination, there is bilateral tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. A photograph of the genital area is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lichen planus is a chronic inflammatory disease of unknown origin that classically manifests with pruritic, planar (flat-topped), polygonal, purple papules and plaques in individuals aged 30–60 years. This condition usually affects the extremities but can also affect the genitals. Although this patient's lesions are mildly pruritic, they do not have the classic morphological features of lichen planus.

B) INCORRECT:

Chancroid is a sexually transmitted infection, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, that can manifest with multiple anogenital ulcers and inguinal lymphadenopathy. However, chancroid ulcers are typically much larger in size (1–2 cm in diameter) than the small ulcers seen in this patient. Although chancroid ulcers can have an erythematous base, they are usually covered in gray-yellow exudates. In addition, chancroid ulcers are typically extremely painful, whereas this patient has reported only mild pain. Moreover, chancroid is extremely rare in the United States.

C) INCORRECT:

Lymphogranuloma venereum, a sexually transmitted infection caused by the L1–L3 serotypes of Chlamydia trachomatis, can manifest with multiple anogenital ulcers. However, these ulcers are characteristically painless and heal spontaneously within a few days. Lymphogranuloma venereum can cause inguinal lymphadenopathy, but it typically develops weeks after the primary infection.

D) CORRECT:

Genital herpes, a sexually transmitted infection caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV), particularly HSV-2, typically manifests with painful and/or pruritic vesicles in the anogenital region. These vesicles rupture easily, leaving punched out, erythematous ulcerations, as seen here. Primary infection with HSV is usually more severe and lasts longer than recurrent infection, and it often manifests with extragenital findings, including tender inguinal lymphadenopathy, dysuria, fever, and malaise. Although genital herpes is typically self-limited, antiviral drugs (e.g., acyclovir, valacyclovir) diminish the severity and duration of episodes and reduce viral shedding. Recurrence, which is caused by the reactivation of dormant virus in ganglion neurons, is common.

Key learning point: Genital herpes typically presents with painful or pruritic grouped vesicles or ulcers on the genitals, often accompanied by tender inguinal lymphadenopathy and systemic symptoms during primary infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Syphilitic chancres, which are sexually transmitted and caused by Treponema pallidum, typically manifest with a firm ulcer with indurated borders and inguinal lymphadenopathy. However, chancres arise as a single painless ulcer rather than multiple painful and pruritic ulcers. Furthermore, the associated lymphadenopathy is usually nontender.
questions.hint: The photograph shows fluid-filled vesicles on erythematous bases in the vulvar and anal areas. Some of these vesicles have ruptured, resulting in erythematous ulcerations.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 3-day history of groin pain. He reports noticing painful vesicles on his penis yesterday, which he has not experienced before. He is sexually active with multiple male and female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. He has no family history of serious illness. He appears ill and uncomfortable. His temperature is 38.2°C, pulse is 78/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 134/80 mm Hg. On examination, there is bilateral tender inguinal lymphadenopathy and multiple grouped vesicular lesions with underlying erythema at the base of the penis. Which one of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A perilesional punch biopsy is indicated for the diagnosis of autoimmune blistering disorders such as bullous pemphigoid and pemphigus vulgaris. These conditions can affect the genital area, but they typically cause blisters rather than vesicles. Tender inguinal lymphadenopathy is not expected in patients with these conditions. Finally, isolated genital involvement is uncommon.

B) CORRECT:

Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) is the preferred confirmatory diagnostic test for HSV infection. Other diagnostic tests include viral culture, which has lower sensitivity than PCR but can also confirm HSV infection, especially in the early stages of infection when fresh vesicular lesions are present. Serum antibody testing is another diagnostic test for HSV infection, but it cannot be used for primary infections because specific antibodies only develop following seroconversion. Tzanck smear is no longer used for diagnosing HSV infections because it has a low sensitivity and specificity and does not differentiate between HSV-1 and HSV-2.

Key learning point: Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) of lesion samples is the most sensitive and specific test to confirm genital herpes simplex virus infection during an active outbreak.

C) INCORRECT:

A Giemsa-stained smear is used to detect Donovan bodies, which are pathognomonic for granuloma inguinale. This condition causes painless genital nodules that eventually ulcerate rather than painful vesicular lesions like the ones seen in this patient. Additionally, granuloma inguinale is not associated with tender inguinal lymphadenopathy and systemic symptoms, both of which are seen here.

Giemsa stain also forms part of the process of Tzanck smear, which is an option for rapid diagnosis of HSV infections. However, Tzanck smear has a low sensitivity and specificity and does not differentiate between HSV-1 and HSV-2. Another study is more appropriate to confirm the diagnosis in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Serological antibody test differentiates between HSV-1 and HSV-2. This test is not used in active, primary genital herpes infections because patients may present before seroconversion. Serological antibody testing is indicated in patients with a history of genital vesicular lesions who have had a negative real-time PCR or viral culture or who have a sexual partner with a known HSV infection. Furthermore, serologic antibody testing is indicated in pregnant women with an active genital lesion to classify the maternal infection as primary or nonprimary and to determine the HSV subtype, because these criteria are important for the prognostication of vertical transmission to the infant.

E) INCORRECT:

Darkfield microscopy is used to detect Treponema pallidum in primary and secondary syphilis when specimens can be obtained from skin lesions (e.g., primary genital lesion, condyloma). Primary syphilis causes genital lesions that are typically single, painless ulcers with indurated borders rather than painful vesicular lesions like the ones seen in this patient. Additionally, patients with primary syphilis develop nontender rather than painful inguinal lymphadenopathy and usually do not have systemic symptoms such as fever and malaise.
questions.hint: Painful vesicular genital lesions in conjunction with bilateral tender inguinal lymphadenopathy should raise concern for genital herpes infection.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male wrestler comes to your clinic with a 5-day history of a very tender rash on his face and neck. He had a low-grade fever on the day the rash began. Over the past 2 days, the rash became vesicular and then crusted. He is currently afebrile. On examination, there are clustered papules with surrounding erythema and overlying crust on his right temple, cheek, ear, and neck (see figure). Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Herpes gladiatorum, which is typically caused by herpes simplex virus type 1, is a common skin infection among wrestlers. It usually manifests as clusters of clear, fluid-filled blisters on an erythematous base that eventually crust over. The lesions spread readily by skin-to-skin contact and are highly contagious until they are completely crusted over. To prevent spread, athletes should not participate in wrestling while the eruption is in the vesicular stage. Like other herpes infections, these lesions may reactivate throughout life. Treatment with oral acyclovir, famciclovir, or valacyclovir should be considered to hasten healing of lesions.

Key learning point: In a wrestler with clusters of clear, fluid-filled blisters surrounded by erythema, the most likely diagnosis is herpes gladiatorum, which is most commonly caused by herpes simplex virus type 1.

B) INCORRECT:

Folliculitis, usually caused by skin bacteria, is an infection of the hair follicle. It results from damage to or blockage of the hair follicle. It manifests as a pimple, boil, or small abscess with a hair in the center. These lesions may be slightly pruritic or painful.

C) INCORRECT:

Impetigo, a bacterial infection most commonly caused by group A streptococcus or Staphylococcus aureus, manifests as weeping patches that quickly develop honey-colored crusts from dried pus (impetigo) or as cloudy fluid-filled vesicles or bullae (bullous impetigo). In adolescents, the lesions often develop on the face, particularly around the nose and mouth.

D) INCORRECT:

Molluscum contagiosum is a viral infection of the skin that is common among young children and adolescents and that is spread by close contact, such as during wrestling. Molluscum presents as individual, flesh-colored, umbilicated dome-shaped papules that become cloudy or red over time as the host’s immune system reacts to them.

E) INCORRECT:

Tinea corporis, a dermatophyte fungal infection, is highly contagious and can be transmitted by skin-to-skin contact and contact with contaminated items. Lesions typically appear as itchy, raised patches with scaly borders and relatively clear centers.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to your clinic by his mother because of fever, malaise, and a painful, itchy rash on his right shoulder that has been present for 2 weeks. His mother reports that the condition has worsened over the past 4 days. He has a history of atopic dermatitis. Since his mother separated from his physically abusive father 2 months ago, they have been living in several public shelters. His immunizations are up-to-date. On examination, there is cervical lymphadenopathy. Laboratory studies are normal. A photograph of the rash is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chickenpox is a highly contagious viral illness that typically manifests with a widespread, pruritic rash that initially involves the trunk and quickly spreads to the face, scalp, and extremities. This patient's underlying skin condition puts him at an increased risk of developing a severe form of chickenpox and complications such as bacterial superinfection and scarring. However, his immunizations are up-to-date and should include the chickenpox vaccine.

B) INCORRECT:

Scabies typically affects the interdigital folds, wrists, and ankles, and patients classically have intense pruritus that is worst at night. Although crowded, unsanitary living conditions are a risk factor for this condition, the rash associated with scabies is not painful. Moreover, fever, malaise, and lymphadenopathy are not expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Crowded living conditions are a risk factor for bed bug infestations. However, bed bug bites take the form of painless papules that becomes itchy and resolve spontaneously within a week. They are typically found on skin that is exposed during sleep.

D) INCORRECT:

Shingles is associated with a rash in a dermatomal distribution, typically affecting 1–3 dermatomes on one side of the body. Most patients report severe burning or throbbing pain that is followed by a rash. The rash is initially maculopapular on an erythematous base and quickly progresses to a vesicular rash. Crusting and involution typically occur after 7–10 days. This patient's immunizations are up-to-date and should include the chickenpox vaccine.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's symptoms (fever, malaise, lymphadenopathy) and his rash indicate eczema herpeticum, a cutaneous manifestation of herpes infection (usually HSV-1 or HSV-2). This condition is associated with pre-existing skin conditions, most often atopic dermatitis. Eczema herpeticum is considered a dermatological emergency because the rash on the patient's shoulder can disseminate rapidly. Treatment with oral or IV acyclovir should be initiated as soon as possible.

Key learning point: Eczema herpeticum is a dermatologic emergency caused by HSV infection in patients with atopic dermatitis, presenting as a painful, rapidly spreading vesicular rash with systemic symptoms and requiring prompt antiviral therapy.
questions.hint: This patient's condition is also known as Kaposi varicelliform eruption.

questions.text: You are seeing a 15-month-old girl who is brought to your clinic with a 2-day history of low-grade fever and a painful lesion on her left middle finger. She was born at term and has been healthy, except for a vesicular rash on her upper lip 2 weeks ago that resolved without treatment. Her temperature is 38.5°C, pulse is 110/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. A photograph of the left middle finger is provided. On examination, she has tender left epitrochlear lymphadenopathy. Which one of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Human papillomavirus type 1 (HPV type 1) is a common cause of verruca vulgaris, also known as common warts. These typically present on the hands and feet as scaly papules, and are usually painless, though they may be pruritic. Since systemic symptoms and lymphadenopathy do not occur in verruca vulgaris, an infection with HPV type 1 can be ruled out.

B) CORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) is the most common cause of herpetic whitlow, an infection of the dermal and subcutaneous tissue of the fingers (especially the thumb and index fingers). It is transmitted through direct contact between a break in the skin on the finger and infected secretions, often from primary oral lesions (e.g., labial herpes), as suggested in this patient. Children who suck their fingers and health care workers (especially dentists) are most commonly affected. The condition presents with painful, grouped, nonpurulent vesicles, usually accompanied by tingling, and burning sensations in the affected digits. Axillary and epitrochlear lymphadenopathy may also develop.

Key learning point: Herpetic whitlow is a painful, nonpurulent vesicular infection of the finger caused most commonly by herpes simplex virus type 1.

C) INCORRECT:

Molluscum contagiosum virus causes localized skin infection and is transmitted through direct skin contact with an infected individual. The lesions are usually painless, flesh-colored, and characteristically dome-shaped with a central umbilication. Typical predilection sites in children are the face, trunk, and extremities. This patient has no history of exposure to an infected individual and her lesions are very different from the lesions of molluscum contagiosum.

D) INCORRECT:

Group A Streptococcus (GAS) causes nonbullous impetigo, which can manifest with small vesicles surrounded by erythema and regional lymphadenopathy. However, this patient's history of a vesicular rash on the upper lip two weeks ago and the presence of systemic symptoms (i.e., fever) make a different condition more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of acute paronychia, a painful soft tissue infection affecting the skin around the nails of fingers and toes. Paronychia is typically purulent, unlike the skin lesion seen in this child, which suggests a nonbacterial etiology.
questions.hint: A Tzanck smear of the vesicular base will show multinucleated giant cells.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl comes to your clinic with a 4-day history of painful vulvar lesions, generalized fatigue, malaise, and dysuria. She is sexually active with two male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Her immunizations are up to date, and she completed the human papillomavirus vaccination course 2 months ago. Her temperature is 38.1°C. On pelvic examination, there are several shallow ulcers with an erythematous base over the labia majora and minora, each measuring 1–3 mm in diameter. She has bilateral, tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. Which one of the following is the most appropriate treatment for her condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A presentation of primary genital herpes in an otherwise healthy adolescent warrants prompt initiation of antiviral therapy with oral acyclovir, famciclovir, or valacyclovir for 7–10 days. This antiviral therapy reduces the duration and severity of infection as well as viral shedding, with maximal effect if begun within 72 hours of symptom onset. It does not, however, decrease the risk of latent infection or recurrence. Subsequent outbreaks are managed with episodic (on-demand) antiviral therapy for two days (started ideally within 24 hours of symptom onset). Daily suppressive therapy to decrease the risk of recurrence (antiviral therapy for up to a year) is reserved for patients experiencing frequent recurrences (≥ 6 in a year).

See “Overview of sexually transmitted genital lesions” table.

Key learning point: Genital herpes presents with multiple painful shallow ulcers and is best treated with oral acyclovir, famciclovir, or valacyclovir.
Image Description:

Photograph of the anogenital region of an adult female patient

Fluid-filled vesicles on erythematous bases are visible around the anus and vulva. Some of these vesicles have ruptured, leaving erythematous ulcerations.

These findings are consistent with herpes genitalis, most likely caused by infection with herpes simplex virus type 2.

B) INCORRECT:

Doxycycline can be used to treat both syphilitic and chlamydial infections but not genital herpes. L1–L3 serotypes of Chlamydia trachomatis cause lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV), which initially manifests as a painless papule that resolves, followed by suppurative lymphadenopathy 2–6 weeks later. Treponema pallidum is responsible for syphilis, which manifests in the primary stage as a painless, round, and firm ulcer with nontender regional lymphadenopathy.

C) INCORRECT:

Curettage is used to treat warts (caused by human papillomavirus) but not genital herpes. Genital warts can be transmitted sexually but present as painless papular growths and are not associated with tender lymphadenopathy, multiple painful shallow ulcers, or malaise.

D) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin is commonly used in the treatment of sexually transmitted infections such as chlamydia and chancroid. Chlamydia infection is commonly asymptomatic; symptomatic patients typically present with pelvic pain, not skin lesions and lymphadenopathy. Chancroid is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi and manifests with multiple painful papules or pustules that erode into ulcers. Chancroid ulcers are usually larger (10–20 mm) and deeper than the ones seen here, and they have a greyish necrotic base and purulent exudate.

E) INCORRECT:

Benzathine penicillin is effective against Treponema pallidum, the causative agent of syphilis. The primary stage of syphilis manifests as a painless, round, and firm ulcer with nontender regional lymphadenopathy.
questions.hint: The presence of several shallow ulcers on an erythematous base and bilateral tender inguinal lymphadenopathy in an individual with high-risk sexual behavior is indicative of genital herpes, which is diagnosed by performing a polymerase chain reaction test or viral culture on a smear obtained from the ulcer.

questions.text: A 22-year-old presents to the ED with a 3-day history of multiple painful lesions on his neck and arms 10 days after participating in a Jiu-Jitsu competition. He is otherwise fit and well with no known past medical history. The lesions began as vesicles on an erythematous base and have now progressed to shallow ulcerations. He reports fever, malaise, and tender lymph nodes in his neck. Physical examination reveals clustered ulcerative lesions on the face, neck, and left lower leg (see photograph). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Impetigo typically presents with honey-crusted lesions and does not follow the distribution pattern or progression described. The vesicular stage followed by ulceration in a contact sport athlete is not characteristic of impetigo.

B) INCORRECT:

Folliculitis involves infection of hair follicles and presents as pustular lesions rather than the vesicular-to-ulcerative progression described. The clustering pattern and systemic symptoms are not typical of folliculitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Eczema herpeticum occurs in patients with preexisting skin conditions like atopic dermatitis, affecting areas of active or healing eczema. This patient has no history of eczema and the distribution pattern is inconsistent with eczema herpeticum.

D) INCORRECT:

Cellulitis presents as erythema, warmth, swelling, and pain but does not have the characteristic vesicular-to-ulcerative progression or the clustered appearance described in this case.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – Herpes gladiatorum is HSV-1 infection that typically occurs in athletes participating in close contact sports. The clinical presentation matches perfectly: multiple vesicles progressing to ulcerations on areas with skin-to-skin contact (head, neck, leg), fever, malaise, and tender regional lymphadenopathy that developed 7 days after a Jiu-Jitsu tournament.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents to the ED with a 3-day history of painful genital lesions. Physical examination shows multiple painful ulcerative lesions on the labia majora and minora with bilateral tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. She denies prior episodes. What is the most appropriate next step in confirming the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While a vaginal wet mount preparation can be used to diagnose trichomoniasis, vaginal candidiasis, and/or bacterial vaginosis, it cannot detect HSV.

B) INCORRECT:

Viral culture can detect HSV and distinguish between HSV-1 and HSV-2 but has lower sensitivity than PCR. Viral culture is primarily indicated when antiviral sensitivity testing is needed.

C) INCORRECT:

The Tzanck test is no longer recommended due to poor sensitivity and specificity. The Tzanck test can detect multinucleated giant cells and Cowdry A inclusions but cannot differentiate between HSV-1 and HSV-2 and is commonly positive in varicella zoster virus infections.

D) INCORRECT:

Direct fluorescent antibody testing can detect HSV antigens and distinguish between HSV-1 and HSV-2 but is not recommended as the first-line test due to poor sensitivity and specificity.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) is the most sensitive laboratory technique for detecting HSV DNA and is the first-line test for confirmation of mucocutaneous HSV infections. PCR can differentiate between HSV-1 and HSV-2 and is specifically indicated for first episodes of genital HSV to establish the diagnosis before initiating treatment.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of painful genital lesions. She describes initial tingling followed by grouped vesicles that have progressed to shallow ulcers. Physical examination shows multiple painful ulcers in the anogenital area. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While nitrofurantoin is used to treat uncomplicated urinary tract infections, it does not treat genital herpes infections.

B) INCORRECT:

While fluconazole is used to treat uncomplicated vulvovaginal candidiasis, it does not treat genital herpes infections.

C) INCORRECT:

While metronidazole is used to treat bacterial vaginosis, it does not treat genital herpes infections.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Acyclovir is an effective treatment for genital herpes infection.

E) INCORRECT:

While doxycycline is used to treat uncomplicated urethritis from chlamydia, it does not treat genital herpes infections.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient with a history of atopic dermatitis presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of worsening skin lesisons affecting the flexor aspects of her knees. The patient reports malaise, feeling hot and sweaty, and development of painful vesicles. Physical examination of the area is shown (see photograph). The patient has tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. Vital signs including temperature are normal. What is the most appropriate initial treatment?

choices.text: Oral acycylovir with outpatient dermatology follow-up
Topical lidocaine gel and oral antihistamines for pain control
Topical mupirocin and oral cephalexin for secondary bacterial infection

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical corticosteroids would be contraindicated as they can worsen this condition.

B) INCORRECT:

While oral acycylovir can be used for eczema herpeticum, this patient's systemic symptoms including malaise and lymphadenopathy suggest a more severe presentation necessitating aggressive therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical anesthetics such as lidocaine should be avoided in eczema herpeticum as they can cause allergic contact dermatitis and further skin irritation. Additionally, topical anesthetics do not address the underlying viral infection and systemic symptoms require antiviral therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

While secondary bacterial infection can occur, the vesicular appearance and distribution over eczematous areas strongly suggests viral etiology requiring antiviral rather than antibiotic therapy as the primary treatment.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – This presentation is consistent with eczema herpeticum, which occurs in areas of active or healing eczema and presents with fever, malaise, and lymphadenopathy. The patient has systemic symptoms, making admission and IV treatment appropriate.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman presents with a two-day history of painful bumps in her genital area, low-grade fever, and malaise. She reports a tingling sensation before the lesions appeared. She has no significant past medical history and recently became sexually active with a new partner. Physical examination reveals clusters of tender vesicles over the labia. No other abnormalities are noted.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chancroid presents with painful ulcerative lesions with ragged, undermined borders, not grouped vesicles. Lesions evolve from papules to ulcers with a necrotic base and are often associated with tender inguinal lymphadenopathy, which are absent here.

B) INCORRECT:

Genital warts, caused by human papillomavirus (HPV), are painless, exophytic lesions that develop gradually. The acute onset of tender, clustered vesicles with systemic symptoms and a prodrome of tingling is inconsistent with the presentation of genital warts.

C) CORRECT:

Genital herpes manifests with painful vesicular lesions on an erythematous base, often accompanied by systemic symptoms such as low-grade fever and malaise. These symptoms suggest a primary herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection, commonly involving HSV-2. The prodromal tingling sensation reflects viral replication along peripheral nerves before lesion formation. The systemic symptoms during the primary infection phase help differentiate it from recurrent episodes, which are generally milder and more localized due to established immune memory.

Key learning point: Painful anogenital vesicles accompanied by systemic symptoms such as fever and malaise are characteristic of genital herpes, caused by the herpes simplex virus.

D) INCORRECT:

Primary syphilis typically presents with a solitary, firm, painless chancre, not clustered, painful vesicles. The prodrome of tingling and systemic symptoms like fever and malaise are more characteristic of genital herpes. Systemic symptoms in syphilis are more common in the secondary stage.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 36 weeks gestation presents to the clinic with recurrent painful vesicular lesions on her genital region. She is concerned about passing the infection to her fetus during delivery. She begins taking daily oral acyclovir.
On her next visit, she asks about the main goal of this treatment. Which of the following is the primary benefit of acyclovir in this scenario?

choices.text: Decreases viral shedding and reduces the duration of active lesions
Prevents transplacental herpes simplex virus infection
Enhances maternal antibody production against herpes simplex virus
Eliminates latent virus from ganglionic neurons

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Acyclovir, a nucleoside analog, is activated by viral thymidine kinase to acyclovir triphosphate, which inhibits viral DNA polymerase. This action disrupts viral DNA synthesis, leading to premature DNA chain termination during active replication. In recurrent genital herpes, acyclovir reduces the duration of active lesions and viral shedding, decreasing the risk of transmission during delivery. This suppression of active viral replication is crucial in managing herpes simplex virus (HSV) infections in pregnant patients to minimize neonatal exposure.

Key learning point: Acyclovir is used in HSV infections to decrease viral shedding and reduce the duration of the current infection, not to increase immunity or prevent transplacental transmission.

B) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir reduces the frequency and severity of HSV reactivation, minimizing viral shedding at delivery. The primary concern is neonatal infection during passage through the birth canal, not transplacental transmission. Transplacental HSV infection is rare and typically occurs during primary infection with viremia, not in recurrent cases.

C) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir inhibits viral DNA polymerase and does not modify immune responses. It does not stimulate B-cell activity or antibody production. Its primary role in managing recurrent genital herpes during pregnancy is to reduce viral shedding and transmission risk, not to enhance maternal antibody production.

D) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir targets active viral replication, not latent virus in ganglionic neurons. During latency, the virus is dormant with minimal enzyme expression, rendering acyclovir ineffective against latent viral genomes. The drug reduces viral reactivation and transmission but does not eradicate the latent reservoir.
